editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: A PLEASANT COMMODIE, CALLED Looke about you.
As it was lately played by the right honourable the Lord High Admirall his ſeruaunts
LONDON, Printed for William Ferbrand, and are to be ſolde at his ſhop at the ſigne of the Crowne neere Guild-hall gate. 1600.

div.head: A pleaſaunt Commodye called Looke about you.
div.stage: Enter Robert Hood a young Noble-man, a ſeruant with him, with ryding wandes in theyr handes, as if they had beene new lighted.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.l: GOe, walke the horſes, wayte me on the hill,
This is the Hermits Cell, goe out of ſight:
My buſines with him muſt not be reueal'd,
To any mortall creature but himſelfe.

sp.speaker: Seru.
sp.l: Ile waite your honour in the croſſe high-way. Exit.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Doe ſo: Hermit deuout and reuerend,
If drouſie age keepe not thy ſtiffened ioyntes,
On thy vnreſtfull bed, or if the houres
Of holy Orizons detayne thee not,
Come foorth.

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: Good morrow ſon, good morrow, & God bleſſe thee Huntington,
A brighter Gleame of true Nobility
Shines not in any youth more then in thee.
Thou ſhalt be rich in honour, full of ſpeed,
Thou ſhalt win foes by feare, and friend, by meede.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Father, I come not now to know my fate,
Important buſines vrgeth Princely Richard, Deliuer letters.
In theſe termes to ſalute thy reuerent age.
Read and be briefe, I know ſome cauſe of truſt,
Made him imploy me for his meſſenger.

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: A cauſe of truſt indeed true honoured youth,
Princes had need in matters of import,
To make nice choyſe faire Earle, if I not erre,
Thou art the Princes ward.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Father I am his ward, his Chamberlaine & bed-fellow.

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: Faire fall thee honourable Robert Hood,
Wend to Prince Richard, ſay though I am loath,
To vſe my skill in Coniuration:
Yet Skinke that poyſoned red cheekt Roſamond,
Shall make appearaunce at the Parlament,
He ſhall be there by noone aſſure his Grace.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Good morrow Father, ſee you faile him not,
For though the villaine did a horrible deed,
Yet hath the young King Richard, and Earle Iohn,
Sworne to defend him from his greateſt foes.

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.p: Gods benizon be with thee noble Earle.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: A dew good father, holla there, my horſe? Exit.

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: Vp, ſpur the kicking Iade, while I make ſpeede
Lye there religion keep thy M. graue,
And on the faire truſt of theſe Princes word
To Court againe Skinke: but before I goe,
Let miſchiefe take aduiſe of villany,
Why to the Hermit letters ſhould be ſent,
To poaſt Skinke to the Court incontinent:
Is there no tricke in this? ha let me ſee?
Or doe they know already I am he?
If they doe ſo, faith weſtward then with Skinke:
But what an aſſe am I to be thus fond,
Heere lyes the Hermit whom I dying found
Some two monthes ſince, when I was howerly charg'd
With Hugh the Cryer and with Conſtables,
I ſaw him in the ready way to heauen,
I helpt him forward, t'was a holy deed;
And there he lyes ſome ſixe foote in the ground,
Since when, and ſince, I kept me in his weedes.
O what a world of fooles haue fill'd my Cell;
For Fortunes, run-awaies, ſtolne goods; loſt cattle,
Among the number, all the faction
That take the young Kings part againſt the olde;
Come to my ſelfe to harken for my ſelfe,
So did the aduerſe party make enquire,
But eyther fall full of contrary deſire:
The olde Kings part would kill me being ſtain'd,
The young Kings keep me from their violence.
So then thou needſt not feare, goe boldly on,
Braue Hall, Prince Dicke, and my ſpruce hot ſpur John,
Heer's their ſafe conduct: O but for Roſamond!
A fig for Roſamond, to this hope Ile leane:
At a Queenes bidding I did kill a queane.

div.stage: Sound Trumpets, enter with a Harrald on the one ſide, Henry the ſecond Crowned, after him Lancaſter, Cheſter, Sir Richard Faukenbridge: on the other part, K. Henry the Sonne crowned, Herrald after him: after him Prince Rich. Iohn, Leyſter, being ſet, enters ſantaſticall Robert of Gloſter in a gowne girt: walkes vp and downe.

sp.speaker: Old. K.
sp.p: Why doth not Gloſter take his honoured ſeate?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: In faith my Liege Gloſter is in a land
Where neyther ſuerty is to ſit or ſtand.
I onely doe appeare as I am ſummoned,
And will awaite without till I am call'd.

sp.speaker: Yon. K.
sp.p: Why heare you Gloſter?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p: Henry I doe heare you.

sp.speaker: Yon. K.
sp.p: And why not King?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p: What's he that ſits ſo neere you?

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: King too.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p: Two Kings? ha ha.

sp.speaker: Ol. K.
sp.p: Gloſter ſit we charge thee.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: I will obey your charge, I will ſit downe,
But in this houſe, on no ſeate but the ground.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p: The ſeat's too good.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p: I know it brother Iohn.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: Thy brother?

sp.speaker: Ol. K.
sp.p: Silence there.

sp.speaker: Yon. K.
sp.p: Paſſe to the billes Sir Richard Faukenbridge.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: My Lieges both, olde Faukenbridge is proude
Of your right honour'd charge. He that worſt may
Will ſtraine his olde eyes, God ſend peace this day.
A bill for the releaſement of the Queene prefer'd,
By Henry the young King, Rich. the Prince, John Earle
Of Murton, Bohmine Earle of Leiſter and the cōmons:

sp.speaker: Old K.
sp.p: Did you preferre this byll?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: We did.
Yee did not well.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Why this is good, now ſhall we haue the hell.
3. Bro Cheſter and Lanchaſter you wrong the King.

sp.p: Our King we doe not.

sp.speaker: Y • n. K.
sp.p: Doe not you ſeeme crown'd?
But whilſt he liues we to none elſe are bound.

sp.speaker: Ley.
sp.l: Is it not wrong thinke you, when all the world
Troubled with rumour of a captiue Queene,
Impriſoned by her husband in a Realme,
Where her owne ſonne doth weare a Diademe?
Is like an head of people mutinous.
Still murmuring at the ſ •••• e done her and vs?
Is't not more wrong when her mother zeale
Sounded through Europe. Affricke, Aſſia,
Tels in the hollow of newes thirſting eares,
Queene Elinor liues in a dungion,
For pitty and affection to 〈◊〉 ſonne:
But when the true cauſe, Cliffords daughters death
Shall be expoſed to ſtranger nations:
What vollumes will be writ. what lybels ſpred?
And in each lyne our ſtate diſhonoured.

sp.speaker: Fauk.
sp.l: My Lord ſpeakes to the purpoſe, mary it may bee ſo,
Pray God it prooue not ſo.

sp.speaker: Ley.
sp.l: Heare me conclude, and there withall conclude,
It is an heynous and vnheard of ſinne:
Queene Elinor daughter to Kingly Fraunce,
King Henries wife and royall Henries mother,
Is kept cloſe priſoner for an acte of Iuſtice,
Committed on an odious Concubine,

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.p: Thou wrongſt her Leiſter.
Leachers euer praiſe the cauſe of their confuſion, ſhe was vile
She was ill ſpoken of it's true, true.

sp.speaker: Gloſr.
sp.l: Yonder ſits one would doe as much for you
Olde foole, young Richard hath a gift I know it,
And on your wife my ſiſter would beſtow it.
Heer's a good world men hate adulterous ſin,
Count it a gulfe, and yet they needs will in.

sp.speaker: Lei.
sp.p: What anſwere for the Queene?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: The King replyes your words are foule ſlaunderous forgeryes

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: His highnes ſayes not ſo.

sp.l: His highnes doth,
Tels you its a ſhame for ſuch wilde youth,
To ſmother any impiety,
With ſhew to chaſtice looſe adulterie.
Say Roſamond was Henries Concubine,
Had neuer King a Concubine but he?
Did Roſamond begin the fires in Fraunce?
Made ſhe the Northerne borders reeke with flames?
Vnpeopled ſhe the townes of Picardy?
Left ſhe the wiues of England husbandles?
O no: ſhe ſinn'd I graunt, ſo doe we all,
She fell her ſelfe, deſiring none ſhould fall;
But Elinor whom you ſo much commend,
Hath been the bellowes of ſeditious fire,
Eyther through Iealious rage or mad deſire;
Iſt not a ſhame to thinke that ſhe hath arm'd
Foure Sonnes right hands, againſt their fathers head,
And not the children of a low-priz'd wretch,
But one whom God on earth hath deified?
See where he ſits with ſorrow in his eyes,
Three of his Sonnes and hers tutor'd by her,
Smiles whilſt he weeps, and with a proude diſdaine,
Imbrace blith mirth, while his ſad heart complaine.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Ha laugh they? nay by the rood that is not wel,
Now fie young Princes fie.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Peace doting foole.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p: Be ſilent aſſe.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: With all my heart my Lords, my humble leaue my Lords
Gods mother aſſe and foole for ſpeaking truth,
Tis terrible, but fare yee well my Lords.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Nay ſtay good Faukenbridge, impute it rage,
That thus abuſes your right reuerend age,
My brothers are too hot.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.p: Too hot indeed, foole, aſſe, for ſpeaking truth? it's more than need.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Nay good Sir Richard at my kinde intreate
For all the loue I beare your noble houſe,
Let not your abſence kindle further wrath,
Each ſide's at counſell now ſit downe I pray,
Ile quite it with the kindeſt loue I may.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p: I to his wife.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Prince Richard Ile ſit downe,
But by the faith I owe fayre Englands Crowne,
Had you not been I would haue left the place,
My ſeruice merits not ſo much diſgrace.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: Good Faukenbridge I thanke thee. Go to their places.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p: And you'l thinke of him, if you can ſtep into his bower at Stepney.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Prince Richard's very kinde, I know his kindenes,
He loues me, but he loues my Lady better,
No more, Ile watch him, Ile preuent his game,
Young Lad, it's ill to halt before the lame.

div.stage: They breake aſunder. Papers this while being offred and ſubſcribed betweene eyther.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Ile not ſubſcribe to this indignity,
Ile not be call'd a King but be a King;
Allow me halfe the Realme, giue me the North,
The Prouinces that lye beyond the Seas,
Wales and the Iſles that compaſſe in the mayne.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p: Nay giue him all and he will ſcant be pleaſ'd.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Brother you aske too much.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: To much, too little, hee ſhall haue that and more, I ſweare he ſhall.
I will haue Nottingham and Salisbury,
Stafford and Darby, and ſome other Earledome,
Or by S. Iohn (whoſe bleſſed name I beare)
Ile make theſe places like a wildernes.
Iſt not a plague, an horrible abuſe,
A King, a King of England ſhould be Father
To foure ſuch proper youths, as Hall, and Dicke,
My brother Geffrey and my proper ſelfe,
And yet not giue his ſonnes ſuch maintenaunce,
As he conſumes among his minions.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Be more reſpectiue Iohn.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Reſpectiue Richard, are you turn'd pure? a changing wether-cocke?
I ſay it's reaſon Henry ſhould be King,
Thou Prince, I Duke, as Ieffry is a Duke.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: What ſhall your Father doe?

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Liue at his prayers, haue a ſufficient pention by the yere,
Repent his ſinnes becauſe his end is neere.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p: A gratious ſonne, a very gratious ſonne.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Will this content you? I that haue ſat ſtill,
Amaz'd to ſee my ſonnes deuoyde of ſhame;
To heare my ſubiects with rebellious tongues,
Wound the kinde boſome of their Soueraigne,
Can no more beare, but from a bleeding hart
Deliuer all my loue, for all your hate:
Will this content thee cruell Elinor?
Your ſauage mother, my vnciuill Queene;
The Tygreſſe that hath drunke the purple bloud,
Of three times twenty thouſand valiant men;
Waſhing her red chaps, in the weeping teares,
Of widdows, virgins, nurſes, ſucking babes.
And laſtly ſorted with her damn'd conſorts,
Entred alaborinth to murther loue.
Will this content you? ſhe ſhall be releaſt,
That ſhe may next ſeaze me ſhe moſt enuyes.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Our mothers liberty is ſome content.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.p: What elſe would Henry haue?

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: The Kingdome.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.p: Peruſe this byll, draw neere let vs conferre.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: Hall be not anſwered but with Soueraignty,
For glorious is the ſway of Maieſty.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.p: What would content you John?

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.p: Fiue Earledomes Sir.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.p: What you ſonne Richard?

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Pardon gratious father, & th'furtheraunce for my vow of penance
For I haue ſworne to God and all his Saints,
Theſe armes erected in rebellious brawles,
Againſt my Father and my Soueraigne,
Shall fight the battles of the Lord of hoaſts,
In wrong'd Iudea and Paleſtina,
That ſhall be Richards pennance for his pride,
His bloud a ſatisfaction for his ſinne,
His patrimony men, munition,
And meanes to waft them into Siria.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Thou ſhalt haue thy deſire Heroyicke Sonne,
As ſoone as other home-bred brawles are done.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Why weepes olde Faukenbridge?

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: I am almoſt blind, to heare ſons cruell, and the fathers kinde,
Now well a neere that ere I liu'd to ſee,
Such patience and ſo much impiety.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Brother content thee this is but the firſt,
Worſe is a brewing, and yet not the worſt.

sp.p: You ſhall not ſtand to this.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: And why my Lord?

sp.speaker: Ley.
sp.p: The lands of Moorton doth belong to Iohn.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: What's that to me, by Acte of Parlament,
If they be mine confirm'd, he muſt be pleaſ'd.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Be pleaſ'd King puppet? haue I ſtood for thee,
Euen in the mouth of death? open'd my armes
To ſercle in ſeditious vgly ſhape?
Shooke hands with duety, bad adew to vertue,
Prophan'd all Maieſty in heauen and earth;
Writ in blacke Carracters on my white brow,
The name of rebell Iohn againſt his Father:
For thee, for thee, thou Otimie of honour,
Thou worme of Maieſty thou froth, thou puble.
And muſt I now be pleaſ'd in peaſe to ſtand,
While ſtatutes make thee owner of my land?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p: Good paſtime good, now will the theeues fall out?

sp.speaker: Joh
sp.l: O if I doe, let me be neuer held
Royall King Henryes ſonne pardon me father,
Pull downe this rebell that hath done thee wrong.
Dicke, come and leaue his ſide, aſſayle him Lords,
Let's haue no parly but with billes and ſwoordes.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: Peace Iohn, lay downe thy armes, heare Henry ſpeake,
He mindes thee no ſuch wrong.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: He were not beſt.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Why hayre-brain'd brother can yee brooke no ieſt?
I doe confirme you Earle of Nottingham.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: And Moorton too?

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: I and Moorton too.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: Why ſo, now once more Ile ſit downe by you.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Blow winde, the youngeſt of King Henries ſtocke,
Would fitly ſerue to make a weather-cocke.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Gape earth, challenge thine owne as Gloſter lyes,
Pitty ſuch mucke is couer'd with the skies.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Be quiet good my Lords, the Kings commaund
You ſhould be quiet, and tis very meere,
It's moſt conuenient, how ſay you Prince Richard?

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: It is indeed.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Why that is wiſely ſaid, you are a very kinde indifferent man,
Mary a God and by my hollidame,
Were not I had a feeling in my head,
Of ſome ſuſpition twixt my wife and him,
I ſhould affect him more then all the world.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Take heede olde Richard, keep thee there mad lad,
My Siſter's faire, and beauty may turne bad.

div.stage: Enter Robert Hood a paper in his hand.

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.p: Roome there, make roome for young Huntington.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.p: A gallant youth, a proper Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Richard I haue had wrong about his wardſhip.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: You cannot right your ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: He can and ſhall.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Not with your help but honourable youth
Haue yee perform'd the buſines I enioyn'd?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: I haue, and Skinke is come, heere is his bill,

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: No matter for his bill let him come in.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Let him not enter, his infectious breath
Will poyſon the aſſembly.

sp.speaker: Gl.
sp.l: Neuer doubt, ther's more infectious breaths about your Throne,
Leyſter is there, your enuious Sonnes is there;
If them you can endure, no poyſon feare.

sp.speaker: Kin
sp.p: Content thee Gloſter.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p: I muſt be content, when you that ſhould mend all are patient,

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Welcome good Skinke thou iuſtly doſt complaine,
Thou ſtandſt in dread of death for Roſamond,
Whom thou didſt poyſon at our dread commaund,
And the appointment of our gratious Mother;
See heere my Fathers hand vnto thy pardon.

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.p: I receiue it gratiouſly, wiſhing his ſoule ſweet peace, in heauen for ſo meritorious a worke, for I feare me I haue not his heart though his hand.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Be ſure thou haſt not, murderous bloud-ſucker,
To iealious enuy executioner.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Beſides thou ſueſt to haue ſome maintenaunce,
We haue bethought vs how wee will reward thee,
Thou ſhalt haue Rowden Lordſhip.

sp.speaker: Gloſt.
sp.p: Shal he ſo? will you reward your murtherers with my lands

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Your lands? it is our gift and he ſhall haue it.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p: Ile giue him ſeaſure firſt with this and this. Strike him.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: Lay holde on Gloſter.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.p: Holde that murtherous Skinke.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Villaines hands off, I am a Prince, a Peere,
And I haue borne diſgrace while I can beare.

sp.speaker: Fau
sp.l: Knaues leaue your rudenes, how now brother
Gloſter? nay be appeaſ'd, be patient brother.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Shift for thy ſelfe good Skinke, ther's golde, away:
Heere will be parts.

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.p: Swonds Ile make one and ſtay.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: I prethee be gone ſince thus it faileth out,
Take water, hence, away, thy life I doubt.

sp.speaker: Ski.
sp.l: Well, farewell, get I once out of doore,
Skinke neuer will put truſt in warrants more. Exit.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.p: Will Gloſter not be bridled?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Yes my Liege and ſadled too, and ryd, and ſpur'd, & rayn'd,
Such miſery (in your Raigne) falles your friends,
Let goe my armes, you dunghyls let me ſpeake.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.p: Wher's that knaue Skinke? I charge you ſee him ſtayd.

sp.speaker: Fauk.
sp.l: The ſwift heel'd knaue is fled, body a me heer's rule,
Heer's worke indeed.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Follow that Skinke, let priuy ſearch be made,
Let not one paſſe except he be well knowne,
Let poaſtes be euery way ſent ſpeedily,
For ten miles compaſſe round about the Citty.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Take Gloſter to you Liefetenant of the Tower,
Keep him aſide till we conferre a while,
Father you muſt ſubſcribe to his committing.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Why muſt he Henry?

sp.speaker: Ley.
sp.p: Mary for this cauſe, he hath broke peace and violated lawes.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p: So haue you all done, rebels as you be.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.p: Good words good brother, heare me gratious Lords,

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: I prethee Faukenbridge be patient,
Gloſter muſt of force anſwere this contempt.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: I will not yeeld he ſhall vnto the Tower,
Warden of th'Fleete take you the charge of Gloſter.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Why be it ſo, yet ſtay with him a while,
Till we take order for the company
That ſhall attend him, and reſort to him.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Warden of the Fleete I ſee I am your charge,
Be friend me thus, leaſt by theyr commaund,
I be preuented of what I intend.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Commaund me any ſeruice in my power.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: I pray you call ſome nimble footed fellow,
To doe a meſſage for me to my ſiſter.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: Call in Redcap, he waiteth with a Tipſtaffe, Exit one for him.
He ſtammers, but he's ſwift and truſly Sir.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p: No matter for his ſtammering, is this he?

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.p: I Iam am Re Redcap ſ ſ ſir.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p: Run Redcap to Stepney.

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.p: Ile be at Stepney p p preſently.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p: Nay ſtay, goe to the Lady Faukenbridge my ſiſter.

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.p: The La La Lady Fau Fau Faukenbreech, I r r run ſir.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: But take thy errand, tell her I am priſoner,
Committed to the Fleete.

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.p: I am g g glad of th th that, my fa fa father the p p porter ſha ſhall ge ge get a f f fee by you. Still runnes.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Stand ſtill a while, deſire her to make meanes
Vnto Prince Richard for my liberty,
At thy returne (make ſpeed) I will reward thee.

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.p: I am g g gone ſi ſir.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Commend me to her gentle Huntington,
Tell her in theſe affayres Ile ſtand her friend,
Her brother ſhall not long be priſoner:
Say I will viſit her immediatlie.
Be gone ſweete boy to Marian Faukenbridge,
Thou lookeſt like loue perſwade her to be louing.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: So farre as honour will I will perſwade,
Ile lay loues battery to her modeſt eares,
Second my milde aſſault, you may chaunce win,
Fare parley at the leaſt, may hap paſſe in. Exit.

sp.speaker: Hen
sp.l: Heere take your charge, let no man ſpeake with him,
Except our ſelfe, our brethren, or Earle Leiceſter.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.p: Not I my Lord, may not I ſpeake with him?

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Yes Faukenbridge thou ſhalt.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: And why? he is his wiues brother.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.p: Earle Iohn, although I be, I am true vnto the State, & ſo is he.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p: What, ſhal I haue no ſeruant of my owne?

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: No but the houſholde ſeruants of the Fleete.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: I thanke you kinſman King, your father knowes,
Gloſter may boldelie giue a baſe ſlaue blowes.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.p: O but not heere, it was not well done heere.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.p: Farewell good Gloſter, you ſhall heare from vs.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Euen what your Sonnes will ſuffer you to ſend;
Iſt not a miſerie to ſee you ſtand,
That ſome time was, the Monarch of this land,
Intreating traytors for a ſubiects freedome?

sp.speaker: Lei.
sp.p: Let him not ſpeake, away with him to priſon.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Heer's like to be a well ſtayd common wealth,
Where in proude Leiſter, and licentious Iohn,
Are pillers for the King to leane vpon.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: Wee'll heare your rayling Lecture in the Fleete.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: On our diſpleaſure ſee he ſpeake no more.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: On thy diſpleaſure, well yee haue me heere;
O that I were within my Fort of Bungye
Whoſe walles are waſht with the cleare ſtreames of Aueney
Then would not Gloſter paſſe a halfe-penny,
For all theſe rebels, and their poore King too.
Laughſt thou King Henry? thou knows my words are true,
God help thee good olde man, adew adew.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: That Caſtle ſhal be mine, where ſtands it Faukenbridge

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Far from your reach ſure, vnder Feckhill ridge,
Fiue hundred men (England hath few ſuch wight)
Keeps it for Gloſters vſe both day and night:
But you may eaſily winne it, wantons words
Quickly can maſter men, tongues out brawle ſwords.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: Yee are an Idyot.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: I prethee Iohn forbeare.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: What ſhall olde winter with his froſty ieſtes,
Croſſe flowry pleaſure?

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: I and nip you too, God mary mother I would tickle you
Were there no more in place but I and you.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Seaſe theſe contentions, forward to the Tower,
Releaſe Queene Elinor, and leaue me there
Your priſoner I am ſure, if yee had power,
Ther's nothing lets you but the Commons feare:
Keep your State Lords, we will by water goe,
Making the freſh Thames, ſalt with teares of woe.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: And wee'll by land through the Citty ride,
Making the people tremble at our pride. Exeunt with Trumpets two waies.

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: Blacke Heath quoth he, and I were King of all Kent,
I would giue it for a commodity of Apron-ſtrings, to
Be in my cottage agen. Princes warrants, mary Skinke
Findes them as ſure as an obligation ſeal'd with butter.
At Kings Bridge I durſt not enter a boate, through
London the ſtones were fiery, I haue had a good
Coole way through the fieldes, and in the high way
To Ratcliffe ſtands a heater: Mile-end's couered with
Who goes there. Tis for me ſure; O Kent, O Kent,
I would giue my part of all Chriſtendome to feele
Thee as I ſee thee. If I goe forward I am ſtayed,
If I goe backward, ther's a roge in a red cap, he's run
From S. Iohnes after me: I were beſt ſtay heere,
Leaſt if he come with hue and cry, he ſtop me yonder,
I would ſlip the coller for feare of the halter;
But heere comes my runner, and if he run for me,
His race dyes, he is as ſure dead, as if a Parlament
Of Deuils had decreed it.

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.l: Ste Ste Stepney chi church yonder, but I haue forgot
The La La Lady Fau Fau Fau plague on her,
I mu muſt b backe to the Fle Fle Fleete to kn kn know it.
The la the la la Lady Fau, plague on't; G Gloſter
Will gone neere to ſt ſtab me, fo for forgetting
My errand, he is ſuch a ma ma mad Lord, the
La Lady Fau Fau Fau.

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: Help me deuiſe, vpon my life this foole is ſent
From Gloſter to his ſiſter Marian.

sp.speaker: Redc.
sp.l: Im muſt nee needs goe backe, the La Lady
Fau Fau Fau.

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.p: God ſpeed good fellow.

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.p: Go go god ſp ſp ſpeed you ſir.

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.p: Why run'ſt thou from me?

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.p: Ma mary ſir, I haue lo loſt a La Ladyes name, and I am running ba backe to ſe ſe ſeeke it.

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.p: What Lady? I prethee ſtay.

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.p: Why the la Lady Fau Fau Fau.

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.p: Faukenbridge?

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.p: I the ſ ſ ſame, f f farewell, I th th thanke you ha hartily

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: If thou wouldſt ſpeake with her ſhe is in Kent,
I ſerue her, what's thy buſines with my Lady?

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.l: I ſh ſh ſhould doe an errand to her f f from my Lord
Of Gloſter, but a a and ſhe be in k Kent, Ile ſ ſend it by you.

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.p: Where is my Lord?

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.p: Mary p p priſoner in the Fl Fleete, a a and w would haue her ſpeake to P Prince R Richard for his re re releaſe.

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.p: I haue much buſines, hold ther's thy fare by water, my Lady lyes this night.

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.p: Wh wh where I pray?

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.p: At Graueſend at the Angell.

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.p: Tis deuilliſh co co colde going by water.

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: Why there's my cloake and hat to keep thee warme,
Thy cap and Ierkin will ſerue me to ride in
By the way, thou haſt winde and ty de, take Oares.
My Lady will reward thee royally.

sp.speaker: Red
sp.p: G God a mercy, f fa faith and euerth thou co co come to the Fl Fl Fleete, Ile giue the tu tu turning of the ke key f for n no nothing.

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.p: Hye thee, to morrow morning at Graueſ-end Ile waſh thy ſtammering throate with a mug of ale merrily.

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.p: God be w with you till ſ ſoo ſoone; what call you the Lady? O now I re remember the La Lady Fa Faukenbridge at what ſ ſigne?

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.p: At the Angell.

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.p: A Angell, the la la Lady fa fa Fau kenbridge, Fa Fau Faukenbridge.

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.p: Farewell and bee hang'd good ſtammering ninny, I thinke I haue ſet your Redcaps heeles a running, wold your Pyanet chattering humour could as ſa ſafely ſe ſet mee fr from the ſearchers walkes. Yonder comes ſome one, hem: Skink to your trickes this tytty tytty, a the tongue I beleeue will faile mee.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Come make vp to this fellow, let th'other go, he ſeems a gentleman, what are you ſir?

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.p: Would I had kept my owne ſute, if the countenaunce carry it away.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Stand ſirra, what are you?

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.p: The po po Porters Sonne of the FFl Fleete, going to Stepney about buſineſſe to the La La Lady Fa Fa Faukenbridge.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Well bring him thether, ſome two or three of yee honeſt neyghbors, and ſo backe to the Fleete, we'll ſhew our ſelues dilligent aboue other Officers.

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.p: Wh wh why le le let me run I am Re Redcap.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Well, ſure you ſhall now run no faſter then I lead you, heare yee neighbor Simmes, I leaue my ſtaffe with yee, bee vigilent I pray you, ſearch the ſuſpitious houſes at the townes end, this Skink's a trouncer; come, will you be gone ſir?

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: Yes ſir, and the deuill goe with you and them,
Well, yet haue hope mad ha hart, co co come your way.

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.p: Sweet nobilitie in reuerſion, Blocke by the commiſſion of his head, Coniures you and withall bindes you, by all the tricks that pages paſſe in time of Parlament, as ſwearing to the pantable, crowning with Cuſtords, paper whiffes to the ſleepers noſes, cutting of tagges, ſtealing of torches, cum multis aliis tell Blocke, what Blocke you haue caſt in the way of my Ladies content.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Block by the antiqiuity of your anceſtrie, I haue giuen your Lady not ſo much as the leaſt cauſe of diſlike, if ſhe be deſpleaſed at any newes I bring, it's more then I muſt blab.

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.p: Zounds theſe pages be ſo proude, they care not for an olde Seruingman, you are a ward and ſo, an Earle, and no more: you diſquiet our houſe that's the moſt: and I may be euen with thee that's the leaſt.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: What Blocke, what Blocke I ſay what doe you there?

sp.speaker: Bloc.
sp.p: Making the young Lord merry Maddame,

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Go attend ye gate, ſee if you can let in more greife therat,

sp.speaker: Blo
sp.p: Zounds and greife come in there, and I ſee him once Ile Coniure his gaberdine.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: will you be gone ſir?

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.p: Hem, theſe women, theſe women, and ſhe bee not in loue eyther with Prince Richard or this lad, let blocks head be made a chopping blocke. Exit Blocke.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Faire Madam, what replye you to my ſute,
The prince excepts ſmiles, welcomes, louing lookes,

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: The Prince, if he giue heed to Marrians ſute,
Muſt heare heart-ſigh's, ſee ſorrow in my eyes,
And finde cold welcome to calamities,

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: And why for gods ſake?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Euen for Gloſters ſake,

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: why by mine honnor, and Prince Richards faith,
Your brother Gloſter ſhall haue liberty,
Vppon condition you releaſe a priſoner
That you haue longe held in captiuitye.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I haue no priſoner,

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Yes a world of eies, your beuty in a willing bondage ties

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Go to, you are diſpoſ'd to ieſt my Lord,

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: In earneſt I muſt be an earneſt ſuter
To you for loue, yet you muſt be my tuter.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Are you in loue?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: I dearely loue Prince Richard.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Then doe you loue the louelieſt man aliue.
The Princelieſt perſon of King Henries ſonnes,

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: I like this well.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: he is vertuous in his minde his body faire,
His deeds are Iuſt, his ſpeaches debonaire,

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Better and better ſtill.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: In deed he is what no body can denye.
All louely, beautie all, all Maieſtie.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Ile tell his excelence what you reporte,
No doubt he will be very thankfull, for't,

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Nay heare you young Lord? Gods pitty ſtaye.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: What haue you more in Richards praiſe to ſay?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I haue ſaid to much if you miſconſter me.
Dutie bids praiſe him, not vnchaſtitie.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Vnchaſtitie holy heauens forfend it,
That he or I, or you ſhould once intend it,

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.p: They are there ſir, cloſe at it, I leaue you ſir, the more Roome the leſſe company.

sp.speaker: Ric
sp.p: Drinke that, farwell,

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.l: If that ſir Richard comes, this ties, this bindes,
O golde, thy power conuerteth ſeruants mindes. Exit.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: How now faire Maddam who hath angred you?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Greife at my brothers duraunce angers me.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: I had thought my Ward young Huntington had vext you

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: who he? alas good Gentleman he wrong'd me not.
No matter for all this, Ile tell your tale.

div.stage: A noyſe within, Enter Skinke, Blocke, Conſtable.

sp.speaker: Bls.
sp.p: Sir there comes no more of you in with him then the Conſtable. Zounds heares a beadroll of Billes at the gate indeed, back ye baſe

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Now ſirra whats the matter?

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.p: Marry heares a ſtammerer taken clipping the Kings Engliſh, and the Conſtable and his watch hath brought him to you to be examin'd.

sp.speaker: Conſta.
sp.p: No Madam wee are commaunded by the King to watch, and meeting this fellow at Mile-end, he tels vs, he is the Porters ſonne of the Fleete, that the Earle of Gloſter ſent him to you.

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.p: Iff forſooth h he deſire you to ſpeake to the p Prince for him.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: O I conceaue thee, bid him blithly fare,
Beare him this Ring in token of my care.

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.p: If I be rid of this euill Angell that haunts mee, many rings, much Fleete will Skinke come vnto.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Madam, if you know this fellow we'll diſcharge him.

sp.speaker: Bloc.
sp.p: Madam, and you be wiſe, truſt your honeſt neighbors heere, let them bring this ca ca ca ca to the Fleete, and ſ ſee your ring deliuered.

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: A plague vpon you for a damned roge,
The Porter of the Fleete will ſurely know me.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Good neighbours bring this honeſt fellow thether,
Ther's for his paines a crowne if he ſay true,
And for your labour ther's as much for you.

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.p: Why Ma Ma Madam, I am Re Re Redcap the Porters ſonne.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Thou haſt no wrong in this, farewell good fellow.

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: Beſt ſpeaking to Prince Richard? no Ile try
And face out Redcap if the ſlaue were by.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Make them drinke Blocke.

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.p: Come to the Buttery bar, ſtitty ſtitty ſtammerer, come honeſt Conſtable, hey the watch of our towne, we'll drinke trylill I ſaith.

div.stage: As they goe out, enters Sir Richard Faukenbridge ſtealing forward, Prince and Lady talking.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Lupus in fabula my Noble Lord,
See the olde foxe Sir Richard Faukenbridge.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: We'll fit him well enough, ſecond vs Robin.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Ile fit you well enough for all your hope, Fau. beckens to Blocke.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.p: Leaue quaffing ſirra, liſten to their talke.

sp.speaker: Bloc.
sp.p:
O while you liue beware, two are ſooner ſeene then one: beſides, beare a braine Maſter, if Block ſhould be now ſpide, my Madam would not truſt this ſconce neither in
time nor tyde.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.p: Well leaue me, now it buds; ſee ſee, they kiſſe.

sp.speaker: Bloc.
sp.p: Adew good olde ſinner, you may recouer it with a fallet of parſly, and the hearbe patience, if not ſir you knowe the worſt, it's but euen this.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Madam, what you deſire I not deny,
But promiſe Gloſters life and liberty,
I beg but loue.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.p: When doth ſhe giue her almes?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Faire honourable Prince.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.p: Nay then they ſpeed.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: My ſoule hath your deſerts in good eſteeme.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.p: Witneſſe theſe goodly times that grace my head.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: But were you the ſole Monarch of the earth,
Your power were inſufficient to inuade,
My neuer yeelding heart of chaſtity.

sp.speaker: Fauk.
sp.l: Sayſt thou ſo Mall, I promiſe thee for this,
Ile owe thy cherry lips an olde mans kiſſe;
Looke how my Cockerill droopes, tis no matter,
I like it beſt when women will not flatter.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Nay but ſweet Lady.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Nay but gracious Lord, doe not ſo much forget your Princely worth,
As to attempt vertue to vnchaſtity.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.p: O noble youth!

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Let not the Ladyes dead griefe for her brother,
Giue life to ſhameleſſe and deteſted ſinne.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.p: Sweet childe.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Conſider that ſhe is of high decent.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.p: Moſt vertuous Earle.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Wife to the nobleſt Knight that euer breath'd.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.p: Now bleſſing on thee bleſſed Huntington.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: And would you then firſt ſtaine your Princely ſtocke,
Wrong beauty, vertue, honor, chaſtitye,
And blemmiſh Faukenbridges vntaynted armes?

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: By adding hornes vnto our Falcones head,
Well thought on noble youth, twas well put in.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Beſides my gratious Lord.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Tickle him Mall, plague him on that ſide for his hot deſire.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: howeuer ſecretly great Princes ſin,

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.p: Oh now the ſpring ſhe'll doe it ſercretly.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: The King of all harts will haue all ſyns knowne.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Ah then ſhe yeilds not.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: Lady heer's my hand, I did but try your honorable faith

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: He did but trie her, would ſhe haue bin tride
It had grone hard on this and on this ſide.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: And ſince I ſee your vertue ſo confirm'd,
as vice can haue no entraunce in your heart,
I vow in ſight of heauen neuer againe,
To mooue like queſtion but for loue,

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.p: My hart is eaſed, holde Blocke take vp my cloake.

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.p: And your cap to ſir.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: Sir Richard?

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: What ſweet Prince welcome yfaith,
I ſee youth quickly get's the ſtarte of age;
But welcome welcome and young Huntington.
Sweet Robyn hude, honors beſt flowring bloome,
Welcome to Faukenbridge with all my hearte,
How cheares my loue, how fares my Marrian, ha?
Be merry chucke, and Prince Richard welcome,
Let it goe Mall I knowe thy greuances.
Away away, tut let it paſſe ſweet girle,
Wee needs muſt haue his helpe about the Earle.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Let it not be delayd deere Faukenbridge.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Sir Richard, firſt make ſute vnto my father,
Ile follow you to Courte and ſecond you,

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Follow to Court, ha? then I ſmell a rat,
Its probable he'll haue about agayne,
Long ſeige makes entraunce to the ſtrongeſt fort,
It muſt not be I muſt not leaue him heere,
Prince Richard, if you loue my brothers good,
Lets ride back to the Courte, Ile wayte on you,

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: He's Ielious, but I muſt obſerue the tyme,
We'll ride vnto the Court, Ile leaue my boy
Till we returne, are you agreed to this?

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Oh I hee is an honourable youth,
Vertuuos and modeſt, Huntingtons right heyre,
His father Gilbert was the ſmoothſt fac't Lord
That ere bare Armes in England or in Fraunce,

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Solicitie Robin, Lady giue good eare,
And of your brothers freedome neuer feare,

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Marrian farwell, wheres Blocke? open the gate,
Come Prince God ſend vs to proue fortunate? Exeunt.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: why doe you ſtay ſir?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Madam as a Lidger to ſolicite for your abſent loue

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Walk in the Garden I will follow you.
I faith I faith you are a noble wagge.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: An honorable wag, and wagiſh Earle.
Euen what you will ſweet Lady I muſt beare,
Hoping of patience, profit will enſue.
That you will beare the Prince as I beare you.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Well ſaid well ſaid, Ile haue theſe toyes amended,
Goe, will you walke into the Garden ſir,

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: But will you promiſe me to bring no maides,
To ſet vppon my litle manſhip there?
You threatned whipping, and I am in feare,

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Vppon my word Ile bring none but my ſelfe,

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: You ſee I am weapned, doe not I beſeech you,
Ile ſtab them come there twenty ere they breech mee. Exit.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: This youth and Richard, think me eaſily wonne,
But Marrian rather will embrace,
The bony carcaſſe of diſmaying death,
Than proue vnchaſt to Noble Faukenbridge,
Richard's king Henries ſonne, is light,
Wanton and loues not humble modeſtie,
Which makes me (much contrary to my thoughts)
Flatter his humor for my brothers ſafetye,
But I proteſt Ile dwel among the dead,
Ere I pollute my ſacred nuptiall bed. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Gloſter in his gowne, calling

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p: Porter what Porter wher's this drowſie aſſe?

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.p: Who calles? my Lord of Gloſter all alone?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Alone and haue your wiſdomes companie,
Pray wher's the ſtammering chatterer your ſonne?
He's euer running but he makes ſmall haſte,
Ile bring his lyther legges in better frame,
And if he ſerue me thus a nother time. Knocke within.
Harke ſir your clients knocke, and't be your pye,
Let him vouchſafe to chatter vs ſome newes.
Tell him we daunce attendance in our chamber. Exit porter.
This Iohn and Henry are ſo full of hate,
That they will haue my head by ſome deuice,
Gloſter hath plotted meanes for an eſcape,
And if it fadge, why ſo; if not, then well,
The way to heauen is death, this life's a hell.

sp.speaker: Port.
sp.l: Why ſhould the Watchmen come along with thee?

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.p: Ther's ſuch a que queſtion for yon ſ ſame r rogue Skink p plague keepe farre enough from him, that a an honeſt f fellow ca cannot w w walke the ſtreetes.

sp.speaker: Port.
sp.l: Well ſir diſpatch your buſines with the Earle,
He's angry at your ſtay I tell ye that. Exit.

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: Sbloud what a frowne this Gloſter caſtes at me,
I hope he meanes to lend me no more cuffes,
Such as he paide me at the Parlament.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: What mutter you, what tydings from my ſiſter?

sp.speaker: Ski.
sp.l: Co commendations and ſ ſhe hath ſ ſent ye this r ring.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Hold ther's two Angels, ſhut the chamber doore,
You muſt about ſome buſines for me ſtrayght;
Come nearer man,

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: I feare I am to neare,

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Haſt thou no tydings for my liberty?

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: No b but ye ſh ſhall he heare f from her p p preſently.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: And p preſently ſir off with your coate.
Nay quicke, vncaſe, I am bold to borrow it,
Ile leaue my gowne, change is no robbery.
Stutterer it's ſo, neare flinch, ye cannot paſſe,
Cry, and by heauen Ile cut thy cowards throate,
Quickly caſhyre your ſelfe, you ſee me ſtaye,

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: N n nay, b b but wh wh what m meane ye?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: To ſcape I hope, ſir with your priuiledge,
How now, who's this, my fine familliar Skinke?
Queene Beldams minnion,

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: Zounds you ſee ti's I.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Tyme ſortes not now to know theſe miſteries.
How thou camſt by this ring, or ſtol'ſt this coate,
They are mine now in poſſeſſion, for which kindenes
If I eſcape Ile get thee Libertie,
Or fire the fleete about the Wardens eares,
Mum budgit not a word as thou loueſt thy life,

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: I mum mum faire, pray God may chaunce it,
My Lord, but that my ſtate is deſperate,
Ide ſee your eyes out eare I would be cheated.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Walke like an Earle villaine ſome are comming.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Where is this Gloſter?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Y y yonder he walks. Fa fa father, I let me out.

sp.speaker: Port.
sp.p: Why whether muſt you now?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p: To Ie Iericho I th thinke, tis ſuch a h h humorous Earle.

sp.speaker: Port.
sp.p: Well ſir wilt pleaſe you haſten home againe.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p: I Ile be h heare in a trice; b but p praye haue ca care of th this madcap, if he g giue vs the ſ ſ ſlip, ſ ſ ſome of vs a are like to m make a ſl ſl ſlyppery occupation on't.

div.stage: This while John walkes and ſtalkes by Skinke, neuer a word betwene them.

sp.speaker: Port.
sp.p: Looke to your buſines ſir let me alone.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p: Alone? neuer truſt me if I trouble thee.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Mad Gloſter mute, all mirth turn'd to diſpaire?
Why now you ſee what tis to croſſe a King,
Deale againſt Princes of the Royall blood,
Youle ſnarle and rayle, but now your toung is bedry'd,
Come caper hay, ſet all at ſix and ſeauen,
What muſeſt thou with thought of hell or heauen?

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: Of neither Iohn I muſe at my diſgrace,
That I am thus kept priſoner in this place.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: O ſir, a number are here priſoners,
My Couſen Moorton whome I came to viſite,
But he good man is at his morrow maſſe,
But I that neither care to ſay nor ſing,
Come to ſeeke that preaching hate and prayer,
And while they mumble vp their Oriſons,
We'll play a game at bowles, what ſaiſt thou Gloſter?

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.p: I care not if I doe,

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: You doe not care, Let olde men care for graues, we for our ſportes,
Off with your gowne, there hes my hatt and Cloake,
The bowles there quickly, hee?

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: No my gowne ſtirres not, it keeps ſorrowe warme,
And ſhe, and I am not to be deuorced,

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Yes ther's an axe muſt part your head and you,
And with your head, ſorrowe will leaue your heart.
But come ſhall I begin? a pound a game,

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.p: More pounds and we thus heauy? well begin.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.p: Rub rub rub rub.

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: Amen God ſend it ſhort enough, and mee
A ſafe running with them clothes from thee.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.p: Play Robin, run run run.

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: Far enough and well, flye one foote more,
Would I were halfe ſo far without the doore.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.p: Now Porter whats the newes?

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Your Cooſſen Moorton humbly craues,
Leauing your game, you would come viſit him,

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Bowle Gloſter Ile come preſently.
So neere mad Robin? then haue after you,

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.p: Would I were gone, make after as you may,

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Well ſir tis yours, one all, throw but the Iacke
While I goe talke with Moorton: Ile not ſtay,
Keepe Cloake and hat in pawne Ile hould out play,

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: I would be ſory Iohn but you ſhould ſtay,
Vntill my bias run another way,
Now paſſe, and hey paſſe, Skink vnto your tricks,
Tis but a chaunce at hazard: there lyes Gloſter,
and heare ſtands Skinke, now Iohn play thou thy part,
And if I ſcape Ile loue thee with my heart.
So porter let me foorth.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: God bleſſe your grace, ye ſpoke with the L. Moorton.

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: I haue and muſt about his buſines to the Courte.
It greeues me to break my ſporte with Gloſter,
The melancholy Earle is comfortleſſe,

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: I wold your grace would comfort him from hence,
The Fleet is weary of his company, Redcap knocks.

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: Drink that, ſome knockes, I prethee let me cut,
His head ſhall off ere long, neuer make doubt. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Iohn at the other doore.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Now madcap thou winſtall; wher art thou Robyn?
Vncaſed: nay then he meanes to play in earneſt.
But whers my Cloake, my rapier, and my hatt?
I holde my birth-right to a beggers ſcrip,
The baſterd is eſcaped in my cloathes.
Tis well, he left me his to walke the ſtreets,
Ile fire the Citty but Ile finde him out,
Perchaunce he hides himſelfe to try my ſpleene,

Ile to his chamber, Gloſter? hallo Gloſter?
Ex ••

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: I wonder how thou camſt ſo ſtrangly chang'd?
Tis not an hower ſince thou wents from hence,

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.p: By my Ch Ch Chriſtendome I ha haue not b b been h heere this three nights, a p p plage of him, that made me ſuch a ch chaunting, and ſ ſent me ſuch a Ia Ia Iaunt, blud I was ſt ſtayd for Skinke, that ill fa fa fac'd rogue.

sp.speaker: Port.
sp.l: I pray God there be no practiſe in this change.
Now I remember theſe are Skinkes cloathes,
That he wore laſt day, at the Parlament,

div.stage: Knocke, Enter at another doore, John in Gloſters gowne.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: Porter? you Porter?

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.p: Doe you not heare them knock, you muſt ſtay ſir,

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: Bloud I could eate theſe rogues.

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.l: Wh wh what raw, tis a very ha • ſh mo morſell,
Ne next your he heart

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: A plague vpon your Iaunts, what porter ſlaue?

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.p: I haue been at g graueſend ſir.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.p: What's that to me?

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.p: And at Ca Ca Canterbury.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: And at the gallows: zounds this frets my ſoule.

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.p: But I c could not f finde your ſ ſ ſiſter the La Lady Fau Faukenbridge.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: You ſtammering ſlaue hence, chat among your Dawes,
Come ye to mad me? while the rogue your father.

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.p: My f fa father.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: Porter? you damned ſlaue.

sp.speaker: Port.
sp.p: Iſt Midſomer doe you begin to raue?

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Harke how the traytor flouts me to my teeth.
I would intreat your knaueſhip let me forth,
For feare I daſh your branes out with the keyes,
What is become of Gloſter and my garments?

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Alas in your apparrell Gloſters gone,
I let him out, euen now I am vndone,

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: It was your practiſe, and to keepe me backe
You ſent Iacke Daw your ſonne with ca ca ca,
To tell a ſleueles tale: lay hould on him,
To Newgate with him and you tut atut,
Run red cap and trudge about,
Or bid your fathers porterſhip farwell. Exeunt with Porter.

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.p: He heares a go good Ie Ie Ieſt by the L Lord to mo mocke an ape withall: my fa fa father has brought his ho ho hoges to a fa fa faire m m m •• ket. Po po porter quoth you? p po porter that will for me, and I po po porter it, let them po po poſt me to heauen in this qua quarter. But I muſt ſ ſ ſeeke this Gl Gl Gloſter and Sk Sk Skinke that co cony catching ra ra raſcall, a pa pa plauge co co confound him, Re re redcap muſt ru run he cannot tell whe whether. Exit

div.stage: Sound Trumpets, Enter Henry the younger, one one hand of him Queene Elinor, on the other Leyceſter.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Mother and •• yceſter adde not oyle to fire.
Wrath's kindled with a word, and cannot heare
The number leſſe perſwaſions you infort,

sp.speaker: Quce.
sp.l: O but my ſonne thy father fauours him.
Richard that vile abortiue changling brat,
And Faukenbridge, are fallen at Henries feete.
They wooe for him, but intreat my ſonne
Gloſter may dye for this that he hath done,

sp.speaker: Leic.
sp.p: If Gloſter liue thou wilt be ouerthrowne,

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.p: If Gloſter liue thy mother dies in moane,

sp.speaker: Ley.
sp.p: If Gloſter liue Leyſter will flie the realme,

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.p: If Gloſter liue thy kingdome's but a dreame,

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Haue I not ſworne by that eternall arme
That puts iuſt vengance ſword in Monarcks hands,
Gloſter ſhall die for his preſumption?
What needs more coniuration gratious Mother?
And honorable Leyſter marke my words.
I haue a Bedrole of ſome threeſcore Lords,
Of Gloſters faction,

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Nay of Henries faction.
Of thy falſe fathers faction, ſpeake the truth,
He is the head of factions; were he downe:
Peace, plenty, glory will impale thy crowne.

sp.speaker: Ley.
sp.l: I ther's the But; whoſe hart-white if we hit,
The game is our's. Well we may rage and roue,
At Gloſter, Lancaſter, Cheſter, Faukenbridge,
But he is the vpſhot.

sp.speaker: Quee
sp.p: Yet begin with Gloſter.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: The deſtenies run to the booke of Fates,
And read in neuer-changing Characters
Robert of Gloſters end he dies to day,
So fate, ſo heauen, ſo doth King Henry ſay.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.p: Emperially reſoul'd. Trumpets far off,
The olde King comes,

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Then comes Luxurious luſt,
The King of Concubines, the King that ſcornes
The vndefiled, chaſt and numptiall bed,
The King that hath his Queene Impriſoned.
For my ſake ſcorne him, ſonne call him not father,
Giue him the ſtile of a competitor,

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Pride ſeaze vppon my heart, wrath fill myne eyes,
Sit lawfull maieſtie vppon my front
Dutie flie from me, pitty bee exild,
Sences forget that I am Henries child,

sp.speaker: Quee
sp.p: I kiſſe thee, and I bleſſe thee, for this thought.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: O Lancaſter bid Henry yeeld ſome reaſon
Why he deſires ſo much the death of Gloſter,

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: I heare thee Henry, and I thus reply.
I doe deſire the death of Baſterd Gloſter.
For that he ſpends the Treaſure of the Crowne.
I doe deſire the death of baſterd Gloſter,
For that he doth deſire to pull me downe.
Or were this falſe (I purpoſe to be plaine)
He loues thee, and for that I him diſdaine.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Therin thou ſheweſt a hate corrupted mynde,
To him the more vniuſt, to me vnkynd,

sp.speaker: Quee
sp.p: He loues you as his father lou'd his mother.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Fie, fie vpon thee hatefull Elinor.
I thought thou hadſt been long ſince ſcarlet dyde,

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: She is and therfore cannot change her colour.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: You are to ſtrickt, Earle Gloſters fault Merrits not death,

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: By th'rood the Prince ſaies true.
Heere is a ſtatute from the Confeſſor,

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: The Confeſſor was but a ſimple foole.
Away with bookes my word ſhall be a lawe,
England her breath ſhall from this boſome drawe,
Gloſter ſhall die,

sp.speaker: Ley.
sp.p: Let Gloſter dye the death.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Leyſter he ſhall not, he ſhall haue lawe, diſpight of him and thee.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: What law, will you be Traitors? whats the lawe?

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: His right handes loſſe, and that is ſuch a loſſe,
As England may lament, all Chriſtians weepe.
That hand hath bin aduanſt againſt the Moores,
Driuen out the Saraſins from Gads and Cicile,
Fought fifteene Battels vnder Chriſts red croſſe,
And is it not (thinke you) a greeuious loſſe,
That for a ſlaue (and for no other harme)
It ſhould be ſundred from his Princely Arme?

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: More for example Noble Lancaſter, but tis great pitty,
To to great a pittie.

sp.speaker: He.
sp.p: Ile haue his hand & head.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: Thou ſhalt haue mine thē.

sp.speaker: Que.
sp.l: Wel ſayd ſtubberne Dicke, Iack wold not ſerue me ſo,
Were the boy heere:

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Both Iohn and I haue ſeru'd your will too long;
Mother repent your cruelty and wrong:
Gloſter you know is ful of mirth and glee,
And neuer elſe did your grace iniury.

sp.p: Gloſter ſhal dye.

sp.speaker: He.
sp.p: Fetch him heere Ile ſee him dead.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: He that ſturs for him ſhall lay downe his head.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: O quiet good my Lords, patience I pray,
I thinke he comes vnſent for by my fay.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: What meanſt thou Gloſter?

sp.speaker: He.
sp.p: Who brought Gloſter hyther?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Let Gloſter hang and them that
There lyes his caſe, a miſchiefe on his carkaſſe.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: My deare ſonne Jacke?

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: Your deere ſon Iack an apes, your mōkey, your babone, your aſſe, your gull.

sp.speaker: Ley.
sp.p: What ayles Earle Iohn?

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Hence further frō my ſight,
My fiery thoughts and wrath haue worke in hand;
Le curſe ye blacker then the Leuarnian Lake,
If you ſtand wondring at my ſorrow thus;
I am with childe, big, hugely ſwolne with rage,
Who'll play the Midwife, and my throbs aſwage?

sp.speaker: Kin
sp.p: I will my Sonne.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: I will high harted brother.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: You will, and you, tut, tut all you are nothing,
Twill out, twill out, my ſelfe my ſelfe can eaſe:
You chafe, you ſwell, ye are commaunding King,
My father is your footeſtoole when he pleaſe,
Your word's a law, theſe Lordes dare neuer ſpeake,
Gloſter muſt dye, your enemies muſt fall.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: What meanes our brother?

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: He meanes that thou art mad ſhe franticke, Leyſter fooliſh
I the babe, theſe grinde vs, bite vs, vexe vs, charge,
And diſcharge, Gloſter, O Gloſter!

sp.speaker: Que.
sp.p: Where is Gloſter ſonne?

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Where is Glo. brother?

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.p: I hope he be eſcaped.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: O I could teare my hayre, & falling thus vpon the
Solide earth, dig into Gloſters graue, ſo he were dead
And gone into the depth of vnder worlds.
Or get ſeditiou • hundreth thouſand hands,
And like Briareus, battle with the Starres,
To pull him downe from heauen if he were there,

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.p: Looke to Earle Iohn the Gentleman is mad.

sp.l: O who would not be mad at this diſgrace?
Gloſter the fox is fled, there lies his caſe,
He couſned me of myne, the porter helpt him,

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: The porter ſhall be hangd let's part and ſeeke him,
Gloſter ſhall dye all Europe ſhall not ſaue him.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: He is wiſe, too wiſe for vs, yet Ile goe with you,
To get more fooles into my company.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.p: This is your fathers plot, reuenge it ſonne.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Father by heauen if this were your aduice,
Your head or heart ſhall pay the bitter price,
Come mother, Brother, Leyſter, lets away,

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: I, Ile be one, in hope to meete the baſterd,
And then no more my ſelfe will be his headſman. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Richard and Faukenbridge follow the ſearch,
You may preuent miſchaunce by meeting Gloſter,
If ye finde Skinke ſee that you apprehend him,
I heare there is a wizard at blacke heath,
Let ſome enquire of him where Skinke remaynes,
Although I truſt not to thoſe fallacies,
Yet now and then ſuch men prooue Soothſayers.
Will you be gone?

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Withall my heart, withall my heart my Lord,
Come Princly Richard, we are ever yoak'd.
Pray God there be no miſtery in this,

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Be not ſuſpitious where there is no cauſe,

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.p: Nay nothing, nothing, I am but in ieſt. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.p: Call in a Purſeuant.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Heares one my Leidge,

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: There is a Porter likely to be hangd,
For letting Gloſter ſcape, ſirra attend,
You ſhall haue a repreiue to bring him vs,
Theſe boys are to to ſtubborne Lancaſter,
But tis theyr mothers fault, if thus ſhe moue me,
Ile haue her head though all the world reproue me. Exeuntt.

stage.hi: Enter Robin Hood and Lady Fankenbridge.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Doe not deny me gentle Huntington.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: My Lord will miſſe me.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Tut let me excuſe thee.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Turne woman, O it is intollerable!
Except you promiſe me to play the Page:
Doe that, try one night, and you'l laugh for euer,
To heare the Orizons that Louers vſe;
Their ceremonious ſighes, their idle oathes,
To heare how you are praiſ'd and pray'd vnto.
For you are Richards Saint, they talke of Mary
The bleſſed Virgin, but vpon his beades
He onely prayes to Marian Faukenbridge.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: The more his error, but will you agree
To be the Lady Faukenbridge one day?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: When iſt?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: On Munday.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Wherefore iſt?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Nay then you doe me wrong with inquiſition.
And yet I care not greatly if I tell thee.
Thou ſeeſt my husband full of iealouſie;
Prince Richard in his ſute importunate,
My brother Gloſter threatned by young Henry;
To cleare theſe doubtes, I will in ſome diſguiſe,
Goe to blacke Heath vnto the holy Hermit,
Whoſe wiſedome in fore-telling things to come,
Will let me ſee the iſſue of my cares.
If deſtinyes ordaine me happines,
Ile chaſe theſe miſtes of ſorrow from my heart,
With the bright Sunne of mirth: if fate agree,
It, and my frends, muſt ſuffer miſery,
Yet Ile be merry too, till miſcheefe come.
onely I long to knowe the worſt of ill.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Ile once put on a ſcarlet countenaunce.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Be wary leaſt ye be diſcouered Robyn.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Beſt paint me then, be ſure I ſhall not bluſh.

div.stage: Enter Block bleeding, Gloſter with him.

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.l: Beate an Officer, Red cap Ile haue ye talkt withall,
Beate Sir Richards Porter? help Madam, help,

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p: Peace you damned rogue.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Brother I pray you forbeare.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Zwonds a hundreth at my heales almoſt,
And yet the villaine ſtands on complaiment.

sp.speaker: Bloc.
sp.p: Abots one you, iſt you?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Will you to the doore you foole? and bar the gate,
Holde ther's an angell for your broaken pate;
If any knocke let them not in in haſte.

sp.speaker: Bloc.
sp.p: Well Ile doe as I ſee cauſe, blood thou art deare to me, but heere's a ſoueraigne plaiſter for the ſore: golde healeth wounds, golde eaſeth heartes: what can a man haue more? Exit.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Deare brother, tell vs how you made eſcape?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: You ſee I am heare, but if you would knowe how:
I cannot ſcape and tell the manner too,
By this I knowe your howſe is compaſſed
With hel-hound ſearch.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Brother Ile furniſh you with beard & hayre, and Garments like my husband, how like you that? Exit. Lady

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Well, when I haue them: quickly then diſpatch • s blood turne gray beard and hayre?
Robyn conceale, this dyeteth my minde,
Myrth is the obiect of my humorous ſpleane,
Thou high commaunding furie! further deuice,
Ieſts are conceated, I long to ſee their birth,
What come ye ſiſter? Robyn a theeues hand,
But prethee where hadſt thou this beard and haire?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Prince Richard wore them hether in a maſke,

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Saiſt thou me ſo, faith loue the Princely youth,
Tut you muſt taſt ſtolne pleaſure now and than,

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: But if ſhe ſteale and Ielious eyes eſpie:
She will be ſure condemnd of Burglary,

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Ha crake? can your low ſtumps venter ſo deep
Into affections ſtreame? go to you wanton.
What want we now? my nightcap, O tis heare,
So now no Gloſter, but olde Faukenbridge,
Harke, the ſearch knockes, ile let them in my ſelfe;
Welcome good fellowe; ha, what iſt you lacke?

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.p: Ma maſter Co conſtable, ſe ſe ſearch you th that way, a and you ho honeſt man th that way. Ile ru run th this way m my owne ſe ſelfe. They diſpearſe themſelues.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p: What ſearch you for? what is it you would haue?

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.p: Madam, what ſhall I doe to theſe browne-bill fellowes? ſome runne into the wine ſeller, ſome heere, ſome there.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p: Let them alone, let them ſearch their filles.

sp.speaker: Block.
sp.p: Ile looke to their fingers for all that.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p: Doe ſo good Blocke, be carefull honeſt Blocke.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Sir ſtammerer & your wa watch, y'are pa paſt ifaith. Exit

sp.speaker: Gl.
sp.p: Will you not ſpeake knaues, tel me who you ſeeke?

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.p: Ma mary ſit we ſ ſeeke a va va vacabond, a fu fugatiue, my La Ladies owne b brother; but and hee were the po po Popes owne b brother, I would ſſearch f f for him; for I haue a p poore fatherr ready to be ha ha hang'd f f for him.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: O tis for Gloſter! mary ſearch a gods name,
Seeke peace, will he breake priſon too?
It's pitty he ſhould liue, nay I defye him.
Come looke about, ſearch euery little corner,
My ſelfe will lead the way, pray you come,
Seeke, ſeeke, and ſpare not, though it be labour loſt:
He comes not vnder my roofe, heare ye wife,
He comes not hyther, take it for a warning.

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.p: You ſp ſp ſpeake like an honeſt ge ge Gentleman, re re reſt you me me mery, co co come my f f friends, I be beleeue h h he r ran by the g g garden w wall toward the wa water ſide. Exeunt running.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: This fellow is of the humour I would chuſe my wife,
Few words and many paces, a word and a way, and ſo
Muſt I: Siſter adieu, pray you for me, Ile do the like for you.
Robin farewell, commend me to the Prince.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Can ye not ſtay heere ſafe?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: No, Ile not truſt the changing humours of olde Faukenbridge,
Adieu yong Earle, Siſter lets kiſſe and part;
Tuſh, neere mourne, I haue a merry hart. Exit.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Farewell all comfort.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: What weeping Lady?
Then I perceiue you haue forgot Blacke-heath.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: No, there Ile learne both of his life and death.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Till Munday Madam I muſt take my leaue.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: You will not miſſe then:

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Nay, if Robin faile yee, let him haue neuer fauour of faire Lady.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Meane while Ile ſpend my time in prayers & teares,
That Gloſter may eſcape theſe threatned feares. Exit.

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: Thus iets my noble Skinke along the ſtreetes,
To whom each bonnet vailes, and all knees bend;
And yet my noble humour is too light,
By the ſixe ſhillings▪ heere are two crackt groates
To helter skelter, at ſome vawting houſe.
But who comes yonder? ha, olde Faukenbridge?
Hath a braue-chaine, were Iohn and he good friends,
That chaine were mine, and ſhould vnto Black-heath
Ile venture, it's but tryal, lucke may fall.
Good morrow good ſir Richard Faukenbridge.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Good morrow my ſweet Prince, harty good morrow,
This greeting wel becomes vs, marry does it;
Better iwis then ſtrife and Iangling.
Now can I loue ye, wil ye to the Shiriffes?
Your brother Richard hath beene there this houre.

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: Yes I am plodding forward as you doe;
What coſt your chaine? it's paſſing ſtrongly wrought,
I would my Golde-ſmith had a patterne of it.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.p: Tis at your graces ſeruice, ſhew it him.

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.p: Then dare ye truſt me?

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Who the Princely Iohn?
My Soueraignes ſonne, why what a queſtion's that?
Ile leaue you, yee may know I dare truſt you.

sp.speaker: Ski
sp.p: Ile bring't ye to the Shiriffes, excuſe my abſence.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.p: I wil my noble Lord, adieu ſweet Prince. Exit.

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: Why ſo, this breakfaſt was wel fed vpon,
When Skinkes deuiſes on Blacke heath doo faile,
This and ſuch cheates, would ſet me vnder ſaile.
Ile to the water ſide, would it were later,
For ſtil I am afraide to meete Prince Iohn.
But what a miſchiefe meant Faukenbridge
To come againe ſo ſoone? that way he went,
And now comes peaking; vpon my life
The buzzard hath me in ſuſpitition,
But whatſoeuer chaunce, Ile filch a ſhare.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Yonder's Prince Iohn I hope he cannot know me,
Ther's naught but Gloſter Gloſter in their mouthes;
I am halfe ſtrangled with the Garlicke breath,
Of raſcals that exclaimes as I paſſe by,
Gloſter is fled, once taken he muſt dye.
But Ile to Iohn, how does my gratious Lord?
What tattles rumour now? what newes of Gloſter?

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: What newes could I heare ſince you left me laſt?
Were you not heere euen now? lent me your chaine,
I thinke you dote.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Sweet Prince, age, age forgets, my brothers chaine? a pretty accident,
Ile haue't and be but in the ſpight of Iohn▪

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: Ther's more, and more, Ile geld it eare it go. He breaks the chaine.
This ſame ſhal keep me in ſome ſauerne merry,
Til nights blacke hand curtaine this to cleare sky.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: My ſweet Prince, I haue ſome cauſe to vſe my chaine,
Another time (when ere your Lordſhip pleaſe)
Tis at your ſeruice, ô mary God it is.

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: Heere palſie, take your chaine, ſtoop and be hang'd,
Yet the fiſh nibled, when ſhe might not ſwallow;
Gout I haue curtall'd what I could not borrow. Exit.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: He's gone away in frets, would he might meete
My brother Faukenbridge in this mad moode,
There would be rare adoe; Why this fits me,
My braine flowes with freſh wit and pollicy.
But Gloſter looke about, who haue we yonder?
Another Iohn Prince, Richard and the Shiriffe?
Vpon my life, the ſlaue that had the chaine,
Was Skinke, eſcapt the Fleete by ſome mad ſleight,
Wel, farewel he, better and better ſtill,
Theſe ſeeke forme, yet I wil haue my will.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Shiriffe, in any caſe be diligent.
Whoſe yonder, Faukenbridge?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p: How now ſweet chucke, how fares my louely Prince?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: What careſt thou? or wel, or ill, we craue no help of thee.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p: Gods mother doe you ſcorne me?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: Gout, what then?

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Fye, leaue theſe idle braules, I prethee Iohn
Lets follow that we are inioyn'd vnto.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: I mary Prince, if now you ſlip the time,
Gloſter wil ſlip away; tut though he hate me
I haue done ſeruice, I haue found him out.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: A ſhame confound thee for thy treachery,
Inconſtant dotard, tymerous olde aſſe,
That ſhakes with cowardiſe not with yeares.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p: Goe, I haue found him, I haue winded him.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: O let me hug thee gentle Faukenbridge,
Forgiue my oft ill vſing of thine age,
Ile call thee Father, ile be penitent,
Bring me where Gloſter is Ile be thy ſlaue,
All that is mine, thou in reward ſhalt haue.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Soft, not too haſty, I would not be ſeene in't,
Mary a god my wife would chide me dead,
If Gloſter by my meanes ſhould looſe his head.
Princely Richard at this corner make your ſtand:
And for I know you loue my ſiſter well,
Know I am Gloſter and not Faukenbridge.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: Heauen proſper thee ſweet Prince in thy eſcape.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Shiriffe, make this your quarter, make good guard.
Iohn, ſtay you heere, this way he meanes to turne,
By Thomas I lacke a ſwoord, body a me.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: What wouldſt thou with a ſwoord olde Faukenbridge?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: O ſir to make ſhew in his defence,
For I haue left him yonder at a houſe
A friends of mine, an honeſt Cittizen.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: Wee'll fetch him thence.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Nay then you iniure me, ſtay till he come; he's in a ruſſet cloake
And muſt attend me like a Seruingman.

sp.speaker: Io
sp.l: Holde ther's my ſwoord, and with my ſwoord my heart,
Bring him for Godſake, and for thy deſert,
My brother King and mother Queene ſhall loue thee.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Marke me good Prince, yonder away we come,
I goe afore and Gloſter followes me;
Let not the Shiriffe nor Richard meddle with vs,
Begin you firſt, ſeaze Gloſter and arreſt him;
Ile draw and lay about me heere and heere,
Be heedfull that your watchmen hurt me not,

sp.speaker: Io
sp.l: Ile hang him that doth hurt thee, prethee away,
I loue thee, but thou kilſt me with delay.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p: Wel keep cloſe watch, ile bring him preſently.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: Away then quickly.

sp.speaker: Gl.
sp.p: Gloſter, cloſe maſter Shiriffe, Prince Richard,

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: Gloſte radieu.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p: I truſt you.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: By my Knight-hood Ile prooue true. Exit Gloſter.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Reuenge, Ile build a Temple to your name;
And the firſt offring ſhal be Gloſters head,
Thy Alters ſhal be ſprinkled with the bloud,
Whoſe wanton current his mad humour fed;
He was a rymer and a Ridler,
A ſcoffer at my mother, prayſ'd my father,
Ile fit him now foral, eſcape and all.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: Take heede ſpight burſt not in his proper gall.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: How now, what way tooke Faukenbridge I wonder?
That is not Gloſter ſure that attends on him.

sp.speaker: Fau
sp.l: He came not at the Shiriffes by the morrow maſſe,
I ſought the Goldſmithes rowe and found him not;
Sirra, y'are ſure he ſent not home my chaine?

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.p: Who ſhould ſend your chaine ſir?

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.p: The Prince, Prince Iohn I lent it him to day.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: What's this they talke?

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.p: By my truth Sir, and ye lent it him, I thinke you may goe look it: for one of the Drawers of the Salutation tolde me euen now, that he had tooke vp a chamber there till euening, and then he will away to Kent.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Body of me, he meanes to ſpend my chaine,
Come Blocke Ile to him.

sp.speaker: Iob.
sp.p: Heare you Faukenbridge?

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.p: Why what a knaue art thou? younders Prince Iohn.

sp.speaker: Bl.
sp.p: Then the Drawer's a knaue, he told me Prince Iohn was at the Salutation.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: Wheres Gloſter Faukenbridge?

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.p: Sweet Prince I knowe not.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.p: Come, ieſt not with me, tell me where he is?

sp.speaker: Fau
sp.p: I neuer ſaw him ſince the Parlament.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Impudent lyar, didſt thou not euen now
Say thou woldſt fetch him? hadſt thou not my ſword?

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Wert thou a King, I will not beare the lye,
Thy ſword? no boy, thou ſeeſt this ſword is myne.

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.p: My Maſter a lyer? Zounds wert thou a potentate,

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: I ſcorne to weare thy armes vntutred childe,
I fetch thee Gloſter? ſhameleſſe did I ſee thee
Since as I went this morning to the Siriffes,
Thou borrowedſt my gold chaine?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: Thy chaine?

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.p: I hope thou wilt not cheate me princkocks Iohn.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Ile cheat thee of thy life if thou charge me
With any chaine.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.p: Come, let him come I pray, Ile whip yee boy, Ile teach you to out face.

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.p: Come, come, come, but one at once, ye daſterds come

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Keepe the Kings peace, I ſee you are both deceau'd,
He that was laſt heare, was not Faukenbridge.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.p: They ſlaunder me, who ſayes that I was heare?

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Wee doe beleeue ye ſir; nor doe you thinke
My brother Iohn deceiu'd you of a chayne.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.p: He did, I did deliuer it with this hand.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.p: Ile dye vpon the ſlanderer,

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.p: Let the boy come.

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.p: I, let him come, let him come.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Fellow, thou ſpakſt euen now, as if prince Iohn
Had byn at ſome olde Tauerne in the towne.

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.l: I ſir, I came vp now, but from the Salutation,
And a drawer that doth not vſe to lye, tolde me
Prince Iohn hath byn there all this after noone.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.p: The Deuill in my likeneſſe then is there.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: The Deuill in thy likeneſſe or thy ſelfe,
Had my gold chaine.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Thou art the Deuill, for thou
Hadſt my good ſword, all theſe can witneſſe it.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.p: Gods Mother thou bely'ſt mee.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: Giue me the lye?

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Nay calme this fury, lets downe to the Tauerne,
Or one, or both, theſe counterfeites are there.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: I know him well enough that had my chaine,
And there be two Iohns, if I finde one there,
Ber Lady, I will lay him faſt.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: It is this Skinke that mockes vs I beleeue.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: Alas poore Skink it is the Deuill Gloſter;
Who if I be ſo happy once to finde,
Ile giue contentment, to his troubled minde.

sp.speaker: Rcih.
sp.l: I hope he's far enough, and free enough:
Yet theſe conſeytes I know delight his ſoule.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.p: Followe me Blocke, follow me honeſt Blocke.

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.p: Much follow you, I haue another peece of worke in hand; I heare ſay Redcaps father ſhall bee hanged this after noone, Ile ſee him ſlip a ſtring though I giue my ſeruice the ſlip; beſide my Lady bad me heare his examination at his death: Ile get a good place, and pen it word for word, and as I like it, ſet out a moornefull Dittie to the tune of Labandalaſhot, or rowe wel ye Marriners, or ſomwhat as my muſe ſhall me inuoke. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Gloſter like Faukenbridge with a Purſeuant, Gloſter hauing a paper in his hand, the Purſeuant bare.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: A charytable deed, God bleſſe the King,
He ſhall be then repreeued.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p:
I ſir, ſome day or two, till the young King and Prince
