Iohn chaunge it, eſpecially if the good Earle bee not found which God forbid.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p: What houſe is this that wee are ſtept into to read this warrant in?

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: A Tauerne ſir, the Salutation,

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: A Tauerne? then I will turne prodigall,
Call for a pint of Sacke good fellow.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: Drawer?

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: Anan ſir.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p: A pint of thy beſt Sacke my pretty youth.

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: God bleſſe your worſhip ſir, ye ſhal haue the beſt in London ſir.

sp.speaker: Gl.
sp.l: What knowſt thou me? knowſt thou old Faukenbridge?
I am no Tauerne hunter I can tell thee.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: But my Maſter hath taken many a faire pound of your man Blocke; he was heere to day ſir, and fild two bottles of nippitate ſacke.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Well, fill vs of your nippitate ſir.
This is well chauneſt, but heere ye boy?
Bring Suger in white paper, not in browne;
For in white paper I haue heere a tricke,
Shall make the Purſeuant firſt ſwound, then ſicke.
Thou honeſt fellow what's thy name?

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: My name is Winterborne ſir.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p: What countryman I prethee?

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: Barkeſhire and pleaſe ye.

sp.speaker: Gl.
sp.p: How long haſt thou bin ſworne a meſſenger?

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.l: But yeſterday and pleaſe your worſhip,
This is the Firſt imployment I haue had.

div.stage: Enter Drawer with wine and Suger.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: A good beginning, heere haue too thee fellow;
Thou art my fellow now thou ſerueſt the King,
Nay take Suger too, Gods Lady deere,
I put it in my pocket, but it's heere:
Drinke a good draught I prethee Winterborne.

div.stage: He drinkes and falles ouer the ſtoole.

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: O Lord Sir Richard, the man, the man.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: What a forgetfull beaſt am I? peace boy,
It is his faſhion euer when he drinkes.
Fellow he hath the falling ſickenes,
Run fetch two cuſhions to rayſe vp his head,
And bring a little Key to ope his teeth. Exit Drawer.
Purſeuant, your warrant and your boxe,
Theſe muſt with me, the ſhape of Faukenbridge
Will holde no longer water heere about.
Gloſter wil be a proteus euery houre,
That Elinor and Leyſter, Henry, Iohn,
And all that rabble of hate louing curres,
May miniſter me more mirth to play vpon.

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: Heer's a key ſir, and one of our folke to help.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: No matter for a key, help him but in,
And lay him by the fire a little while,
He'll wake immediatly, but be hart ſicke,
Ther's money for a candle and thy wine,
Ile goe but vp vnto your Aldermans,
And come downe preſently to comfort him. Exeunt

sp.speaker: Within Ski.
sp.p: Drawer? what Drawer? with a vengeance Dra.

sp.speaker: Within Dra,
sp.p: Speake in the Crowne there.

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: They be come, the deuill crowne yee one by one,
Skinke tho' art betraide, that maſter Faukenbridge
Miſſing ſome of his chaine, hath got thee dog'd.
Drawer? what Drawer?

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: Anan, anan ſir.

sp.speaker: Ski.
sp.p: Was not ſir Richard Faukenbridge below?

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: Yes and pleaſe yee.

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.p: It does not pleaſe me wel, knowes he that I am heer?

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: No I proteſt.

sp.speaker: Ski.
sp.l: Come hether ſirra, I haue little money,
But ther's ſome few linkes of a chayne of golde:
Vpon your honeſty knowes not ſir Richard,
That I am heere?

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: No by my holydam.

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.p: Who's that was with him?

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: Why a Purſeuant.

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.p: Where is ſir Richard?

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: At the Aldermans.

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: A Purſeuant and at the Aldermans.
What Pyg, or Gooſe, or Capon haue you kill'd,
Withing your Kitchin new?

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: A pyg new ſtickt.

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: Fetch me a ſawcer of the bloud, quicke run; Exit.
Ile ſit the Purſeuant, and Alderman,
And Faukenbridge, if Skinke haue any wit.
Well Gloſter, I did neuer loue thee yet,
But th'art the maddeſt Lord that ere I met,
If I ſcape this, and meete thee once againe,
Curſſe Skinke, if he dye penny in thy det.

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: O my Lord the houſe is full of holberts, and a great many Gentlemen aske for the roome where Prince Iohn is?

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: Lend me thy Aprone, runne and fetch a pot from the next roome.
Betray'd, ſwounds betray'd, by gout, by palſie, by dropſie;
O braue boy, excellent bloud: vp, take my cloake
And my hat to thy ſhare, when I come from Kent, ile pay
Thee like a King.

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: I thanke you my Lord. Exit.

div.stage: Enter John, Richard. Faukenbridge, Shiriffes and Officers.

sp.speaker: Ski.
sp.p: Now fortune help or neuer: they come, and yee were a Prince as yee ſay ye are, yee would bee aſhamed to abuſe a poore ſeruant thus, but and if you were not of the bloud Royall, Ide breake the necke of yee downe the ſtayres, ſo would I, Ide teach you to hurt prentiſes.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: Who hurt thee fellow?

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.p: Prince deuill or his dam, Prince Iohn they call him.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.p: Gloſter I hope.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: I doubt not but it's Skinke.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: Where is he?

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: Vp them ſtayres, take heede of him.
He's in the Crowne.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.p: Alas poore fellow, he hath crown'd thee ſhrewdly.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: In recompence, if it be him I ſeeke,
Ile giue thee his whole head to tread vpon.
Follow me brother, come olde Faukenbridge,
Keep the ſtayres Shiriffes, you ſee it waxeth darke,
Take heede he ſlip not by you. Exeunt

sp.speaker: Ski.
sp.l: Hange your ſelues, this darkenes ſhal conuay me out, of doors
Ile ſwim the Thames, but Ile attaine Black-heath,
London farewell, curſe Iohn, raue Faukenbridge,
Skinke ſcapes you all by twy lights priuyledge.

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.p: Where is he? lights, bring lights, drag out that boy.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: This is my cloke, my hat, my rapier,
And eyther it was Skinke or Gloſter.

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: I know not who twas ſir, he ſaid he was Prince Iohn, he tooke away my aprone and a pottle pot with him, and al to bloudied his head and face.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.p: We met him, by S. Anthony, we met him.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: The fire of S. Anthony confound
This changing counterfeit whatſoeuer he be.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: It makes me laugh at enuious greedines,
Who feedes vpon her owne harts bitternes.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Sirra you that were borne to cry anan,
What other copeſmates haue you in the houſe?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Sir, my Maiſters geſſe be none of my copeſmates,

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: Well your geſſe, can ye geſſe who they be?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.l: Marry heere's a purſeuant, that this Gentleman ſir
Richard Faukenbridge left ſick euen now.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.p: Marry of God dyd I, thou lying knaue?

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: I am a poore boy ſir, your worſhip may ſay your pleaſure, our maides haue had a foule hand with him, you ſaid he would be ſicke: ſo he is with a witneſſe.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Looke about Faukenbridge, heere's worke for you,
You haue ſome euill Angell in your ſhape,
Goe ſirra, bring vs foorth that Purſeuant?

div.stage: Enter two leading the Purſeuant ſicke.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Gloſter, thou wilt be too too venterous,
Thou dooſt delight in thoſe odde humours ſo,
That much I feare they'll be thy ouerthrowe. aſide.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: O O O not too faſt; O I am ſicke, O very ſicke.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: What picture of the peſtilence is this?

sp.speaker: Purſ.
sp.p: A poore man ſir, a poore man ſir: downe I pray yee, I pray let me ſit downe. A ſir Richard, ſir Richard, a good ſir Richard: what haue I deſeru'd to be thus dealt with all at your worſhips hands? a ha, ah, ah.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.p: At my hands knaue? at my hands paltry knaue?

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: And I ſhould be brought to my booke oath ſir:

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.p: What Ieffrey?

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: Anan, anan.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.p: A plague vpon your Ieffring, is your name Ieffrey?

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: I and't pleaſe you ſir.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Why gentle Ieffrey then ſtay you awhile,
What can you ſay, if you come to your booke?

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: If I bee poſ'd vpon a booke ſir, though I bee a poore prentiſe, I muſt ſpeake the truth, & nothing but the truth ſir.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: And what's your truth ſir?

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: O, O my heart.

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: Mary ſir this Knight, this man of worſhip.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.p: Well, what of me? what did my worſhip doe?

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: Mary ye came into the Bel, our roome next the Barre, with this honeſt man as I take it.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.p: As thou tak'ſt it?

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: O ſir tis too true, too true, too true O Lord.

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.l: And there he call'd for a pint of Sacke, as good Sacke
(Ile bee poſ'd vpon all the bookes that euer opened and ſhut) as any is in all Chriſtendome.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.p: Body of me, I come and call for Sacke?

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: O ye did, ye did, ye did, O O.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.p: Well forward ſirra.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: Gloſter hath done this ieſt.

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: And you call'd then for Suger ſir, as good Suger and as wholſome, as euer came in any cup of Sacke: you drunke to this man, and you doe well God be thanked, but hee no ſooner drunke:

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: But I, but I, but I, O my head, O my heart.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: I cannot chuſe but ſmile at theſe conſeites.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: I am mad, and yet I muſt laugh at Faukenbridge:
Brother, looke how ſir Richard actes his rage?

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: I came? I call? the man is like to dye,
Practiſe by th'emafſe, practiſe by the marry God,
Iohn loues me not, Prince Richard loues my wife,
I ſhall be charg'd heere, for a poyſned knaue.
Practiſe by th'Lord, practiſe I ſee it cleare.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: And more Sir Richard, O Lord O Sir Richard,

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: What more? what haſt thou more? what practiſe more?

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.l: O my box, my box, with the Kings armes, O my box,
O my box, it coſt me, O Lord euery penny O, my box,

sp.speaker: Rcih.
sp.p: And what of your box ſir.

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: Mary ſir it's loſt, & tis wel knowne my Maſter keeps no theeues in his houſe, O there was none but you and he.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.p: O then belike thou thinkeſt I had his box,

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: O ſir Richard I will not, O Lord I will not charge you for all the world, but, but, but for the warrant the olde King ſignd to repreeue the Porter of the fleet, O God, O God!

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.p: The Porter of the Fleet, the olde king ſignd,

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: I my good Lord, oh, oh,

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: Is he repreiued then?

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: No my Lord, O ſir Richard tooke it from me with his owne hand, O.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Heeres a deuice to bring me in contempt
With the olde King, that I euer lou'd,
Princes and Shiriffe, you can witneſſe with me,
That I haue bin with you, this after noone,
Onely with you, with no body but you,
And now a fellow whome the King would ſaue,
By a repreiue, this fellow ſayes is hang'd,

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: If thou hadſt done it, Ide haue iuſtified it,
But Richard I conceipt this ieſt already,
This mad mate Skinke, this honeſt merry knaue,
Meeting this Purſeuant, and hearing tell
He had a warrant to repreeue a ſlaue,
Whome we would hang: ſtole it away from him.
This is ſure the Ieſt, vpon my life it is,

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: O but my warrant, how ſhall I doe? O,

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: But looke about you, hot braind brother Iohn,
And I beleeue you'l finde it otherwiſe,
Gloſter hath got the warrant in diſguiſe,
And ſau'd the fellow you ſo faine would hang.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: No, no, how ſay you M. Shiriffe, is he not hang'd?

sp.speaker: Shi.
sp.l: My Lord, the gibbet was ſet vp by noone
In the olde Bayly, and I charg'd my men,
If I returne not, though it were by Toarch light,
To ſee him executed ere they come.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: I am greedy to heare newes.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Rob'd of my chaine, out-fac'd I had a ſwoord,
Accuſ'd of poyſoning, couſonage, ſeeking bloud?
Not to be borne: it is vntollerable.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Sir Richard, I prethee haue ſome patience.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Ile to Blacke-heath, talke not of patience,
It is intollerable, not to be borne.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: It is intollerable not to be borne,
A warrant brother, Faukenbridge a warrant?

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.p: I ſaw no warrant, I defie you all.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: A ſlaue, a Purſeuant, one winter borne.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.p: I care not for thee that winter borne.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: O it is I ſir, that's my warrant.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Iſt you? you rogue, you drunkerd; yeare cheated,
And we are cheated of the priſoner,
Out dog, dog.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: O ô ô ô my Lord. Exit and Drawer.

sp.speaker: Shi.
sp.p: Haue patience and we wil haue a priuy ſearch.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Goe hang ye block-heads, get ye from my ſight,
O would I were a Baſiliske, to kill
Theſe gleare ey'd villaines.

sp.speaker: Shir.
sp.l: Come away let's leaue him, Exeunt Shiriffes and Officers.
We haue a warrant let him doe his worſt.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Ile to Blacke-heath, Ile to the holy Hermit,
There ſhall I knowe not onely theſe deceiuers,
But how my wife playes faſt and looſe with Richard.
Ha, I ſhall fit them, Ile tickle them,
Ile doo't, Ile hence, Ile to the Heath amaine, Exit.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: There ſhall I know, where this damned Gloſter is,
Ile haue the Deuils rouſ'd to finde that Deuill,
Or elſe Ile coniure the olde Coniurer.
Ile to Blacke-heath, and there with friends conſpire,
But Ile haue Gloſters head my hearts deſire.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Would mad Earle Robyn ſaw theſe humouriſtes.
Twol'd feed him fat with Laughter; O twold ſit him,
Where euer he is, I knowe the bate conſaite
Is better to him than his daintieſt foode,
Well, and it fits mee well, now I haue time,
To coort my Lady Faukenbridge at leyſure,
Loue I emplore thy aide faire Cipria,
Thou ſea-borne mother at affections ring,
Shine brightly in thy ſphere, that at my ſtarre,
My plannet thou of all lights moſt beautious,
Be thou to my deſires Auſpitious. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Robin Hood in the Lady Faukenbridges gowne, night attire on his head.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: O for this Lady, was neuer poore Gentleman troubled with Gentlewoman as I am with my ſelfe, my Lady Faukenbridge hath fitted me a turne, heere I am viſited with ſleeueleſſe errands and with asking for this thing Madam and that thing Madam, that they make me almoſt mad in earneſt, whoop heer's another Client.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Heer's my Lady Rawfords Page attends to ſpeake with your Ladyſhip.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: I pray ye bid her Lordſhips Page come into my
Ladyſhip: well Robin Hood, part with theſe pettycoates,
And caſt theſe looſe deuices from thy backe,
Ile nere goe more vntruſt, neuer bee kercheft.
Neuer haue this adoe, with what doe you lacke?

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.l: Madam my Lady greets your honour kindely,
And ſends you the firſt grapes of her young vine.

sp.speaker: Rob
sp.p: I am much indepted to her honour, thers an angel for you to drinke; ſet them vp till after ſupper. Humphery, pray looke about for Blocke. Humphery? truſt mee I thinke the foole be loſt.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: No forſooth, Madam hee's vpon the greene Ieſting with a ſtammerer, one Redcap.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: It is a lewd fellowe, pray bid him come in youth, Ile giue him his welcome at the doore: commend me to your Lady, I pray ye hartily. Exit Page

Humphrey, I maruell where ſir Richard is ſo late? truely, truely hee does not as beſeemes a gentleman of his calling, pray let ſome goe foorth to meete him on the greene, and ſend in that blockehead Blocke. Exit Humphrey.

div.stage: Enter Redcap and Blocke after him.

sp.speaker: Bloc.
sp.p: Wil ye tel tales ye aſſe, will ye?

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.p: Ile te te tell your La La Lady or I would to g God we were ha hang'd elſe, as my fa father ſhould haue bin.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Now what's the matter there I pray you? what company haue you there a gods name? where ſpend you the day I pray?

sp.speaker: Bloc.
sp.p: Why where you gaue me leaue, at the gallows I was, no farther.

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.p: A a and you be his La Lady, you are the La Lady Fau Faukenbridge, the Earle of glo Gloſters ſiſter.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: I am ſo fellow.

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.p: Y y your man b b Blocke heere, does no nothing but f f floute m me, a and cr cries r run Re Redcap ad ſ ſ ſee your f f father ha ha hang'd. I ſh ſhal g go neere to m make m murder and he v vſe it.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Wel firra, leaue your mocking you were beſt, Ile bob your beetle head and if you mocke him.

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.p: He's run Redcap.

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.p: La la law ma Madam.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Away ye ſaucy foole, goe waite within.

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.p: Run Redcap, run Redcap. Exit.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Art thou the Porters ſonne, that was condemned about my brother Gloſter?

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.p: I g g God be with ye, I am the p p Porters ſon, I m muſt r run to ſ ſ ſeeke your b br brother.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Wel, drinke that fellow, if thou finde my brother bee not too violent, and Ile reward thee.

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.p: I th th thanke ye h hartily, and I had not bin couſoned with Sk Skinke, I had no nee need of theſe ia iaunts, for Gl Gloſter was ſ ſafe enough.

stage.hi: Enter Blocke and the Porter with his cloake muffled.

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.p: Ah farewel Redcap.

sp.speaker: Red,
sp.p: Fa fare we wel and be ha hang. Exit.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: You'll neuer leaue your knauery, whoſe there more?

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.p: One Madam that hath commendations to you from your brother.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Commeſt thou from Gloſter? thou art welcome friend

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.p: O it's one of the kindeſt Ladies (though ſhe wil now & then haue about with Block) that euer breath'd and ſhe had been in her mood now, Redcap would haue made her ſuch ſp ſp ſport as't a pa pa paſt.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Wil you make ſport and ſee who knockes againe?

sp.speaker: Bl.
sp.p: Our gates are like an Anuile, from foure to ten, nothing but knicke a knocke vpon't. Exit.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Wil you be gone ſir? honeſt friend I am glad
My brother Gloſter got thy liberty,
Whoſe flight was cauſe of thy captiuity:
Nor ſhal there be in vs ſuch negligence,
Though thou haue loſt thy Office and thy houſe,
But we wil ſee thee better farre prouided,
Than when thou wert porter in the Fleete.

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.l: Madam your olde friend Prince Richard,
All alone, making mone, fetching many a greeuous grone.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Prince Richard come ſo late? lights to his chamber,
Sirra, in any caſe ſay I am ſicke.

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.p: Very ſicke, ſicke and like to dye: Ile ſing it and you wil.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Away ye knaue, tel him, in the morning
Ile humbly waite vpon his excellence.

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.p: That's all his deſire to haue ye lowly and humble, and tis a courteous thing in a Lady. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Hence, or elſe ile ſet you hence: goe in good friend.
Come Lady Faukenbridge, it's time to come,
Robin can holde out no longer I ſee,
Hot wooers will be tempters preſently. Exit

sp.speaker: Ski.
sp.l: Now holy Skinke in thy religious weed,
Looke out for purchaſe, or thy wonted clyants:
Warrents quoth you, I was fairely warrented,
Young Robin Hood the Earle of Huntington,
Shall neuer fetch me more vnto his Prince.
sp.stage: Enter Ladie Faukenbridge in Merchants wiues attyre.
sp.l: But pauca verba Skinke, a prize, a prize,
By th'mas a pretty girle, cloſe Hermit cloſe,
Ore-heare if thou canſt, what ſhe deſires,
For ſo my cunning and my credit ſpreads.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: See how affection armes my feeble ſtrength,
To this ſo deſperate iourneying all alone,
While Robin Hood young Earle of Huntington,
Playes Lady Faukenbridge for me at home.

sp.speaker: Ski.
sp.l: What miſtery is this? the Lady Faukenbridge,
It's ſhe, ſweet fortune thou haſt ſent her wel,
I will intice this morcell to my Cell:
Her husband's iealious, I will giue him cauſe,
As he beleeues, I hope it ſhall ſucceed;
Nay ſwounds it ſhal, ſhe's mine in ſcorne of ſpeed.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: By this broad beaten path, it ſhould appeare,
The holy Hermits Caue cannot be farre,
And if I erre not, this is he himſelfe.

sp.speaker: Ski.
sp.p: What honour'd tongue enquereth for the Hermit?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: What honour'd tongue?

sp.speaker: Ski.
sp.l: I Lady Faukenbridge,
I know ye, and I know for what you come.
For Gloſter and your husbands iealouſie.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: O thou, whoſe eye of contemplation,
Lookes through the windows of the higheſt heauens,
Reſolue thy Hand-maide, where Earle Gloſter liues:
And whether he ſhal liue, and ſcape the hate,
Of proude young Henry and his brother Iohn?

sp.speaker: Ski.
sp.l: Ile haue you firſt in, Ile tel you more anone.
Madam, they ſay buſhes haue eares and eyes,
And theſe are matters of great ſecrecy:
And you'll vouchſafe enter my holy Cell,
There what you long to know, ile quickely tell.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Stay heere are ſtrangers.

sp.speaker: Ski.
sp.l: A plague vpon them, come they in the nicke,
To hinder Raynald of his Foxes tricke?

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: Good day olde Hermit.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.p: So to you faire Dame.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: By Elinors gray eye ſhe's faire indeed;
Sweet heart come ye for holy benizons?
Hermit haſt thou good cuſtome with ſuch Cliants?
I cannot blame your feates, your iugling trickes,
Plague iuggle you.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Why curſſe ye ſacred worth?

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Ill done in ſooth my Lord, very ill done,
Wrong holines: a very pretty woman.
Mocke grauity; by the maſſe a cherry lippe,
A it's not wel done, deride a holy Hermit?

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.p: I haue it in my purſe ſhall make amends.

sp.speaker: Ski.
sp.l: His purſe and yours, ſhall make me ſome amends,
For hindring me this morning from the Lady;
For ſcaring me at Tauerne yeſternight,
For hauing backe your chaine, Ile fit you both.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: Hermit, a word.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.p: A word with you faire miſtreſſe.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Where lye your deuils that tel all your newes?
Would you would trouble them for halfe an houre,
To know what's become of traytor Gloſter,
That in my cloathes brake priſon in the Fleete?

sp.speaker: Ski.
sp.p: No, it was Skinke.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: Come olde foole yee dote.

sp.speaker: Ski.
sp.p: But heare me.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.p: Heare him Prince.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: Swounds who heares you? Ile make your Lady graft ye for this worke: but to your tale ſir.

sp.speaker: Ski.
sp.l: Knowe thriſe honour'd Prince, that Skinke did couſen
Redcap of his cloathes.
Gloſter did couzen Skinke, and ſo eſcapt.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: Well done Faukenbridge?

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.p: My Lord, he tels you true.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: You finde it on her lippes: but forward ſir.

sp.speaker: Ski.
sp.l: Twas Skinke in Gloſters gowne, whome you did viſit,
That playd at bowles and after ſtole your cloths,
While you went into the Lord Moortons chamber.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: This ſauors of ſome truth,

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.p: Tis very like,

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.p: Well Faukenbridge by heauen Ile tell your wife,

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: She'l much beleeue you: you will come?
Tell me of my wife: this euening faile me not.
My wife quoth you: Ile ſend my wife from home,
Do, tell my wife prince Iohn, by my deare mother,
I loue her too too well to like another.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: It ſeemes ſo fox, O what a world is this,
There moſt ſinne raynes where leaſt ſuſpition is,

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.p: You'l come.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I will not faile, I warrant you,

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: Hermit is all this true,

sp.speaker: Ski.
sp.l: Himſelfe deliuer not ſo much before ye ſleepe,
Roote me from out the borders of this Realme.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Well by your leaue ſir Richard Faukenbridge,
Hence free from feare, you'l melt you'l melt olde man,

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Nay take her to you, ſhe is a ſhrow I warrant,
Ile to the holy Hermit, and inquire,
About my chaine your ſword, the Purſeuant
And other matters that I haue to aſke.

sp.speaker: Ski.
sp.p: Your welcome good ſir Richard,

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Nay doe not ſtand on tearmes, I am fire, all life,
Nor neuer tell me that I haue a wife.
I doe not meane to marry, ye think ſo,
But to be merry, you the manner knowe.
And you will haue me, haue me, poynt a meeting,
Ile be your true loue, you ſhall be my ſweeting,
If you deny to promiſe, this is plaine
Ile haue my will eare you get home againe.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: moſt gratious Lord.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Tut tell not me of grace I like no goodnes but a beautious face.
Be therefore breefe, giue me your hand & ſweare,
Or Ile away with you into the heath,
Neither ſhall Faukenbridge nor Hermit helpe,
And what I doe Ile anſwer well enough.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Why, then my Lord.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Nay do not ſtand on then,
But tell me when my Lord ſhall haue you Lady,
Its preſently, ile venter for a baby.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: This night at ſtepney by my ſummer houſe,
There is a tauerne which I ſometime vſe,
When we from London come a goſſoping,
It is the Hinde,

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Giue me thy pretty hand.
Thou'lt meet me at the Hinde, Ile by thy Roe,

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: One word's enough,

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.p: Suffice then be it ſo,

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Ile fit my olde adulterer and your grace,
Ile ſend the Princeſſe thether in my place.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Prince Iohn, Prince Iohn the Hermit teles me wonders.
He ſayes it was Skinke that ſcapt vs at the Tauerne,
Sk nke had my chaine: nay ſure that Skinke did all.

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: I ſay goe but to yonder corner,
And ere the Sun be halfe an hower higher,
Ther will the theefe attempt a robery,

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: Who Skinke?

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.p: Will Skinke?

sp.speaker: Ski.
sp.p: I Skinke vpon my word.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.p: Shal we goe ſeaze vpon him good Prince Iohn?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Nay we will haue him that's no queſtion.
And yet not hurte the honeſt rogue.
he'll helpe vs well in queſt of changeing Gloſter,
Hermit farwell, Lady keepe your houre.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.p: Adeiu olde Hermit: ſoone in th'euening Laſſe,

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Ile meet you both, and meet with both of you.
Father what anſwere doe you giue to me?

sp.speaker: Ski.
sp.l: Lady ſtart downe I muſt into my cell,
Where I am curing of a man late hurt,
He dreſt, I muſt vnto my Orizons,
In halfe an houre al wil be diſpatcht,
And then I will attend your Ladyſhip.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: At your beſt leaſure father, O the life
That this thriſe reuerend Hermit leadeth heere.
How farre remote from mortall vanities,
Baites to the ſoule, enticements to the eye?
How farre is he vnlike my luſtfull Lord?
Who being giuen himſelfe to be vnchaſte,
Thinke all men like himſelfe, in their effects,
And iniures me, that neuer had a thought,
To wrong the ſacred rytes of ſpotleſſe faith.

div.stage: Enter Skinke with a patch on his face, and a Faulconers lure in his hand.

sp.speaker: Ski.
sp.p: Hermit farewel, ile pay ye or ſpeake with ye next time I ſee yee. Sweete mouſe the Hermit bids you ſtay heere, he'll viſit you anon. Now Iohn and Faukenbridge, Ile match yee, and I doe not ſay Skinke's a wretch, a wren, a worme, when I haue trickt them, Madam I will trimme you. Commodity is to be prefer'd before pleaſure. About profit Skink, for crownes for crownes, that make the kingly thoughts.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I am aſſur'd that man's ſome murderer, Exit.
Good Father Hermit ſpeake and comfort me,
Are ye at prayers good olde man? I pray ye ſpeake,
What's heere a beard? a counterfeited hayre?
The Hermits portes? garments and his beades?
Ieſus defend me I will fly this denne,
It's ſome theeues caue, no haunt for holy men.
What if the murderer, (as I ges him one)
Set on my huſband, tuſh Prince Iohn and hee
Are able to defend them noble ſelues,
How eare, I will not tarry, Ile away,
Leaſt vnto theft and rape, I prooue apray. Exit.

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: Younder they are Ile fit them, heer's my ground:
Wa ha how, wa ha how, wa ha how?

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.p: I warrant ye my Lord ſome man's diſtreſt.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.p: Why man tis a Faulconer.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Mary of me good fellow, I did think thou hadſt bin robd.

sp.speaker: Ski.
sp.p: Rob'd, ſir no, he that comes to rob me ſhal haue a hard match on't, yet two good fellows had like to bin rob'd by one tall theefe, had not I ſtept in: abots on him, I loſt a hauke by him, & yet I car'd not to ſend another after him, ſo I could find the theefe; and here about he is. I know he is ſquatted.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Sayſt thou me ſo? we'l finde him by S. Mary.
An honeſt fellow, a good common wealths man.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: There are caues heereabout good fellow, are there not?

sp.speaker: Ski.
sp.p: Yes ſir, tread the ground ſir, & you ſhal heare their hollownes, this way ſir this way.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: Help Faukenbridge.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.p: O help me good prince Iohn.

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.p: Ile helpe you both, deliuer ſir deliuer, Swounds linger not: Prince Iohn put vp your purſſe, or ile throw ponniards downe vpon your pate. Quickely, when? I am Skink that ſcapt ye yeſternight, and fled the Fleete in your cloake, carrying mee cleane out of winde and raine. I broke the bonds and linkes that fettered your chaine amity, this cheate is mine: Farewel I cannot ſtay, ſweet Prince, olde Knight, I thanke ye for this pray.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Gods mary mother, heer's a ieſt indeed,
We came to take, a theefe takes vs:
Where are ye good my Lord?

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: No matter where, I thinke I was fore-ſpoken at ye teate,
This damn'd rogue ſeru'd me thus? Gloſter and he
Vpon my life conclude in villany.
He was not wont to plot theſe ſtratagems,
Lend me your hand a little, come away,
Let's to the Cell againe, perchaunce the Hermit
Is Skinke, and theefe, and Hermit al in one.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Mary a God then ten to one its ſo,
Wel thought on Princely Iohn,
He had my chayne, no doubt he had your ſwoord.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: If there be now no Hermit at the Cel,
Ile ſweare by al the Saints its none but he. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Gloſter in the Hermits gowne, putting on the beard.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: This accident hath hit thy humour Gloſter,
From purſeuant ile turne a Hermit now.
Sure he that keeps this Cell is a counterfeit,
Elſe what does he heere with falſe hayre and beard?
Well how ſo eare it be, Ile ſeeme to be
The holy Hermit: for ſuch fame there is,
Of one accounted reuerend on this heath.

sp.speaker: Ski.
sp.l: Ile faine vnto my cell, to my faire Lady,
But Iohn and Faukenbridge are at my heeles.
And ſome od mate is got into my gowne,
And walks deuoutly like my counterfeite,
I cannot ſtay to queſtion with you now,
I haue another gowne, and all things fit,
Theſe gueſts once rid, new mate? Ile bum, Ile marke you.

sp.speaker: Gl.
sp.l: What's he a gods name? he is quickly gone,
I am for him, were he Robin-good fellow,
Whoſe yonder the Prince Iohn and Faukenbridge?
I thinke they haunt me like my genii,
One good the other ill, by th'mas they prye
And looke vppon me but ſuſpitiouſly.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: This is not Skinke, the Hermit is not Skinke:
He is a learned reuerend holy man.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: He is he is a very godly man.
I warrant ye, he's at his booke at's prayers,
Wee ſhould haue tooke you, by my hollydam
Euen for a very theefe.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Now God forfend ſuch noblemen as you ſhould geſſe me ſo,
I neuer gaue ſuch cauſe for ought I knowe.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Yet thou didſt tell vs Skinke ſhould doe a roberye,
Appoynted vs the place, and there we found him,

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.p: And he felt vs, for he hath rob'd vs both.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p: He's a lewd fellow, but he ſhall be taken.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: I had rather heere of Gloſter then of him.

sp.speaker: Glo
sp.l: Gloſter did cheat him, of the ſame golde chaine,
That deceiu'd Sir Richard Faukenbridge.
He got your ſword Prince Iohn: twa's he that ſaude
The porter, and beguil'd the Purſeuant,

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.p: A vengaunce on him.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p: Doo not curſſe good Prince, he's bad enough, twere better pray for him.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Ile kill thee, and thou bid me pray for him.
Ile fell woods, and ring thee round with fire,
Make thee an offring vnto fierce reuenge,
If thou haue but a thought to pray for him.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p: I am bound to pray for all men, chefely chriſtians.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Ha ha, for chriſtians, thinkſt thou he is one?
For men: haſt thou opinion he is a man?
He that changes himſelfe to ſundry ſhapes,
Is he a chriſtian? can he be a man?
O, Irreligious thoughts,

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p: Why worthy Prince I ſaw him chriſtened, dept into the font

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Then nyne times like the northen laplanders,
He backward circled the ſacred Font,
And nyne times backward ſayd his Oriſons,
As often curſt the glorious hoaſt of heauen,
As many times inuocke the fiends of hell,
And ſo turn'd witch, for Gloſter is a witch.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Haue patient Gentle Prince, he ſhall appeare,
Before your Kingly father ſpeedily.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Shall he indeed? ſweet comfort kiſſe thy cheeke,
Peace circle in thy aged honoured head,
When he is taken: Hermit I proteſt
Ile build thee vp a chappell and a ſhrine:
Ile haue thee worſhipt, as a man deuine,
Aſſure he ſhall come, and Skinke ſhall come.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p: I that ſame Skinke, I prethee ſend that Skinke,

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: Send both, and both as priſoners crimminate
Shall forfeite their laſt liues to Englands ſtate,
Which way will Faukenbridge?

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.p: Ouer the water, and ſo with al ſpeed I may to Stepney

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: I muſt to Stepney too, and reuile, and be blith,
Olde winke at my mirth, t'may make amends,
So thou, and I, and our friends, may be friends,

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Withall my heart, withall my heart Prince,
Olde Faukenbridge will waite vppon your grace,
Be good to Gloſter for my Marrians ſake,
And me and myne you ſhall your ſeruants make,

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Of that anon my pleaſure being ſeru'd,
Gloſter ſhall haue what Gloſter hath deſeru'd.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.p: Why, that's well ſaid, adew good honeſt Hermit, Exit.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Hermit farwell, if I had my deſire,
Ile make the world thy wonderous deeds admire, Exit.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Still good, ſtill paſſing good, Gloſter is ſtill
Henryes true hate, foe to Iohns froward will.
No more of that for them in better tyme,
If this ſame Hermit be an honeſt man,
He will protect me by this ſimple life,
If not I care not, Ile be euer Gloſter,
Make him my foot ſtole if he be a ſlaue,
For Baſeneſſe ouer worth can haue no power.
Robin be thinke thee, thou art come from Kings.
Then ſcorne to be ſlaue to vnderlings,
Looke well about thee Lad and thou ſhalt ſee,
Them burſt in enuy that would iniure thee.
Hermit Ile meet you in your Hermits gowne,
Honeſt, Ile loue you: worſe, Ile knocke you downe. Exit.
Kinde friends, wee haue troubled Lady Faukenbridge,
And eyther ſhe's not willing to be ſeene,
Or els not well: or with our boldneſſe greeu'd,
To eaſe theſe I haue brought you to this window,
Knowing your are in muſicke excellent,
I haue pend a ditty heere: and I deſire
You would ſing it for her loue and my content,

sp.speaker: Muſi.
sp.p: With all my heart my Lord.

div.stage: Enter Robin Hood like the Lady.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Your excellence forgets your Princely worth,
If I may humbly craue it at your hands,
Let me deſire this muſicke be diſmiſt.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: For beare I pray and with draw your ſelues.
Be not offended gratious Marrian, Exeunt Muſicke.
Vnder the vpper heauen, nine goodly ſpheres,
Turne with a motion euer muſicall,
In Pallaces of Kings, meliodious ſound
Offer pleaſures to ther ſoueraignes eares.
In Temples, milke white clothed queriſtors,
Sing ſacred Anthemes bowing to the ſhrine,
And in the feelds whole quires of winged clarkes,
Salutes the morning bright and Chriſtaline,
Then blame not me, you are my heauen, my Queene,
My ſaint, my comfort, brighter then the morne,
To you all muſicke, and all praiſe is due.
For your delight you for delight was borne,
The world wold haue no mirth, no ioy, no day,
If from the world your beautie were away.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Fie on loues blaſphemie and forgery,
To call that in, thats onely miſery,
I that am wedded to ſuſpitious age,
Solicited by your laſciuious youth,
I that haue one poore comforte liuing,
Gloſter my brother, my hie harted brother,
He flies for feare, leaſt he ſhould faint and fall
Into the hands of hate tirannicall.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: What would you I ſhould doe?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: I would full faine, my brother Gloſter had his peace againe.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Shall loue be my reward if I doe bring
A certaine token of his good eſtate.
And after pacyfie my brothers wrath?
Say you'l loue, we'l be fortunate,

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: I will.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: No more, I vow to dye vnbleſt
If I performe not this inpoſed queſt,
But one word Madam pray can you tell,
Where Huntington my ward is?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: I was bold to ſend yong Robin Hood your noble ward
Vpon ſome buſines of import for me.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: I am glad he is imployde in your affayres,
Farewell kinde faire, let one cloudy frowne
Shaddow the bright ſunne of thy beauties light.
Be confident in this, ile finde thy brother,
Rayſe power but we'l haue peace, onely performe
Your gratious promiſe at my backe returne.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Wel, heer's my hand, Prince Richard that ſame night
Which ſecondeth the day of your returne,
Ile be your bedfellow, and from that houre
Forſweare the loathed bed of Faukenbridge:
Be ſpeedy therefore, as you hope to ſpeed.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: O that I were as large wing'd as the winde,
Then ſhould you ſee my expeditious will:
My moſt deſire, adew, gueſſe by my haſte,
Of your ſweet promiſe the delicious taſte. Exit.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Why ſo: I am rid of him by this deuiſe,
He would elſe haue tyred me with his ſighes and ſongs,
But now I ſhall haue eaſe, heere comes the Saint,
To whom ſuch ſute was made.

sp.speaker: Bl.
sp.p: My Lady Gentlewoman is euen heere in her priuitye walke, Madam heer's the Marchants wife was heere yeſterday would ſpeake with yee; O I was ſomewhat bolde to bring her in.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Wel leaue vs ſir; y'are welcome gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.l: Theſe women haue no liberality in the world in them,
I neuer let in man to my Lady, but I am rewarded.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Pleaſe ye to walke ſir? wherfore mumble ye?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Robin what newes? how haſt thou done this night?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: My Ladiſhip hath done my part, my taske,
Lyne all alone for lacke of company,
I might haue had Prince Richard,

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Was he heere?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: He went away but now; I haue bin lou'd & wood too ſimply,
God rid me of the woman once againe,
Ile not be tempted ſo for all the world,
Come, wil you to your chamber and vncaſe?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Nay keep my habit yet a little while,
Olde Faukenbridge is almoſt at the gate,
I met him at Black heath iuſt at the Hermits,
And taking me to be a Merchants wife,
Fell mightily in loue, gaue me his ring,
Made me proteſt that I would meete him heere.
I tolde him of his Lady, O tut quoth he,
Ile ſhake her vp, ile packe her out of ſight,
He comes kinde Robin Hood, holde vp the ieſt.

div.stage: Enter Sir Rich. Faukenbridge and Blocke.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.p: Gods mary knaue, how long hath ſhe bin heere?

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.p: Sir ſhe came but euen in afore you.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: A cunning queane, a very cunning queane,
Go to your buſines Block, ile meete with her.

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.p: Ah old Muttonmounger I beleeue heer's worke towards. Exit.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Doe not beleeue her Mall, doe not beleeue her:
I onely ſpake a word or two in ieſt,
But would not for the world haue bin ſo mad,
Doe not beleeue her Mall, doe not beleeue her:

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: What ſhould I not beleeue? what doe you meane?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Why good Sir Richard, let me ſpeake with you,
Alas wil you vndoe me? wil you ſhame me?
Is this your promiſe? came I heere for this?
To be a laughing ſtocke vnto your Lady

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: How now Sir Richard, what's the matter there?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Ile talke with you anon, come hyther woman?
Didſt not tel my wife what match we made:?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I tel your wife? thinke ye I am ſuch a beaſt?
Now God forgiue ye, I am quite vndone.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.p: Peace duck, peace ducke, I warrant al is wel.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: What's the matter? I pray ye ſir Richard tell me?

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Mary Mall thus, about ſome twelue monthes ſince,
Your brother Gloſter, that mad prodigall,
Cauſ'd me to paſſe my word vnto her husband,
For ſome two thouſand pound: or more perchaunce,
No matter what it is, you ſhall not know,
Nay ye ſhal neuer aske to know.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: And what of this?

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Mary the man's decayde,
And I beleeue a little thing would pleaſe her;
A very little thing, a thing of nothing.
Goe in good Mall, and leaue vs two alone,
Ile deale with ye as ſimply as I can.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Fox looke about ye, ye are caught yfaith.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Deale with her ſimply, ô ho; what kinde of dealing?
Can ye not deale with her and I be by?

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Mary a God, what are ye iealous?
Ye teach me what to doe: in, get you in.
O I haue heard Prince Richard was your gueſt,
How dealt you than? In get you in I ſay,
Muſt I take care about your brothers debts,
And you ſtand croſſing me, in, or ile ſend you in. Exit Robin.
Ha ſirra, you'l be maſter, you'l weare the yellow,
You'l be an ouer-ſeer: mary ſhal yee.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Ye are too curſt (me thinkes ſir) to your Lady;

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Ah wench content thee, I muſt beare her hard,
Elſe ſhe'l be prining into my dalliances:
I am an olde man ſweet girle I muſt be merry,
All ſteele, al ſpright, keep in health by change,
Men may be wanton, wowen muſt not range.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: You haue giuen good counſel ſir, ile repent me,
Heer's your ring, ile onely loue my husband.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: I meane not ſo, I thinke to day thou toldes me
Thy husband was an vnthrift, and a bankrout,
And he be ſo, tut thou haſt fauour ſtore,
Let the knaue beg, beauty cannot be poore.

sp.speaker: La
sp.l: Indeed my husband is a bankrout,
Of faith, of loue, of ſhame, of chaſtity,
Dotes vpon other women more then me.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Ha doe he ſo? then giue him tit for tat,
Haue one ſo young and faire, and loues another,
He's worthy to be coockolded by the maſſe.
What is he olde or young?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: About your age.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: An old knaue and cannot be content with ſuch a peate,
Come to my cloſet girle, make much of me,
We'll appoint a meeting place ſome twiſe a weake,
And ile maintaine thee like a Lady, ha?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: O but you'll forget me preſently,
When you looke well vpon your Ladies beauty.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Who vpon her? why ſhe is a very dowdy,
A diſhclout, a foule Iipſie vnto thee,
Come to my cloſſet laſſe, there take thy earneſt
Of loue, of pleaſure and good maintenaunce.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I am very fearefull.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Come foole neuer feare I am Lord heate, who ſhall diſturb as then?
Nay come, or by the rood Ile make you come,

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Help Madam Faukenbridge for gods ſake.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.p: How now, what meanſt?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Help Gentle Madam help,

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: How now what aylſt thou?

sp.speaker: Bloc.
sp.p: Nay and't be a woman, nere feare my maſter Madam

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Why ſpeakſt thou not, what aylſt thou?

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.p: Why nothing, by the rood nothing ſhe ayls.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: O Madam this vile man would haue abuſed me,
And forcſt me to his cloſſet,

sp.speaker: Rob,
sp.p: Ah olde cole, now looke about, you are catcht,

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Call in your fellowes blocke,

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Doe not thou knaue,

sp.speaker: La,
sp.p: Doe or Ile cracke your crowne,

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.p: Nay Ile doo't, I knowe ſhe meanes to ſhame you. Exit.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Why Mall wilt thou beleeue this paultrie woman?
Huſwife Ile haue you whipt for ſlaundring me.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: What Leacher, no ſhe is an honeſt woman,
Her husband's well knowne, all the houſhold knowes.

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.p: Heer's ſome now, to tell all the towne your mynd,

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Before ye all I muſt ſure complaine,
You ſee this wicked man, and ye all knowe
How oft he hath byn Iealous of my life,
Suſpecting falſhood being falſe himſelfe;

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.p: O maiſter, O maiſter,

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: She ſlaunders me, ſhe is a couſoning queane,
Fetch me the Conſtable, Ile haue her puniſht,

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: The Conſtable for me fie, fie vpon ye.
Madam do you know this ring?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: It is ſir Richards.

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.p: O I, that's my maſters too ſure.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: I mary, I did lend it to the falſe drab
To fetch ſome money for that bankrout knaue
Her husband, that lyes priſoner in the Fleete.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: My husband bankrout? my husband in the Fleete priſoner?
No, no, he is as good a man as you.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: I that he is, and can ſpend pound for pound
With thee yfaith, wert richer then thou art,
I know the gentleman.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Nay Madam he is hard by, there muſt be Reuelles at the Hinde to night;
Your copeſmate there, Prince Iohn.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Ther's a hot youth.

sp.speaker: Bl.
sp.p: O, afierce Gentleman.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: He was fierce as you, but I haue matcht him,
The Princeſſe ſhall be there in my attyre.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: A plaguy crafty queane, mary a God
I ſee Prince Iohn, coorted as well as I,
And ſince he ſhal be mockt as well as I,
Its ſome contentment.

sp.speaker: Bl.
sp.l: Maſſe he droopes, fellow Humphrey, he is almoſt taken,
Looke about ye old Richard?

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Hence knaues, get in a little, prethee Mall
Let thou and I and ſhe, shut vp this matter.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Away ſirs, get in.

sp.speaker: Bl.
sp.p: Come, come let's goe, he wil be baited now, farewel old Richard. Exit

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Now ſir, what ſay you now?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Mary ſweet Mall I ſay I met this woman, likt her, lou'd her,
For ſhe is worthy loue I promiſe thee;
I ſay I coorted her: tut make no braule
Twixt thou and I, we'l haue amends for all.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Had I done ſuch a tricke, what then? what then?

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.p: Ah prethee Mall, tut beare with men.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: I, we muſt beare with you; you'l be excuſ'd,
When women vndeſerued are abuſ'd.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Nay doe not weep, pardon me gentle Lady,
I know thee vertuous, and I doo proteſt,
Neuer to haue an euill thought of thee.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: I, I, ye ſweare, who's that that will beleeue ye?

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Now by my holy dam and honeſt faith,
This Gentlewoman ſhall witnes what I ſwea e.
Sweet Ducke a little help me?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Truſt him Madam.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: I will be kinde, credulous, conſtant euer,
Doe what thou wilt, ile be ſuſpitious neuer.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: For which I thanke noble Faukenbridge.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.p: Body of me who's this? yong Huntington?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: And I your Lady whome you coorted laſt,
Ye lookt about you ill, foxe we haue caught ye,
I met ye at Blacke heath, and ye were hot.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: I knew thee Mall, now by my ſwoord I knew thee,
I winkt at all, I laught at euery ieſt.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: I, he did winke, the blinde man had an eye.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Peace Robin, thou't once be a man as I.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Well, I muſt beare it all.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Come, & ye beare, its but your office, come forget ſweet Mall.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I doe forgiue it and forget it ſir.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Why that's well ſaid, that's done like a good girle:
Ha ſirra, ha you matcht me pretty Earle?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: I haue, ye ſee ſir I muſt vnto Blacke heath,
In queſt of Richard, whom I ſent to ſeeke
Earle Gloſter out, I know he's at the Hermits;
Lend me your Coach; Ile ſhift me as I ride,
Farewell ſir Richard. Exit.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Farewell Englands pride, by the mattins Mall it is a pretty childe;
Shall we goe meete Iohn? ſhall we goe mocke the Prince?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: We will.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: O then we ſhall haue ſport anon,
Neuer weare yellow Mall, twas but a tricke,
Olde Faukenbridge wil ſtil be a mad Dicke. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.p: Doe ye ſ ſ ſay fa fa father Hermit, th that Gl Gloſter is about this Heath?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: He is vpon this Heath Sonne looke about it,
Run but the compaſſe, thou ſhalt finde him out,

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.p: R r run? ile r run the co compaſſe of all k Kent but Ile f finde him out, my f f father (where ere hee layes his head) dare ne neuer co come home I know, t t till hee bee fo fo found.

sp.speaker: Gl.
sp.p: Wel thou ſhalt find him, knowſt thou who's a hunting?

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.p: M m mary tis the Earles of La La Lancaſter and Le Leyſter. Fa fa farewell f father, and I finde Skink or Glo Gloſter, Ile g g giue thee the pr priſe of a penny p p pudding for thy p paines.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Adew good friend: this is ſure the fellow
I ſent on meſſage from the Parlament.
The Porters ſonne, he's ſtill in queſt of me,
And Skinke that couſoned him of his red cap.
sp.stage: Enter Richard like a Seruing man.
sp.l: But looke about thee Gloſter, who comes yonder?
O a plaine ſeruingman, & yet perhaps his bags are lyn'd,
And my purſſe now growes thin: if he haue any I muſt ſhare with him.
And who's on yond ſide? O it is my Hermit,
Hath got his other ſute ſince I went foorth.

sp.speaker: Ski.
sp.l: Sbloud yonder's company, ile backe againe,
Elſe I would be with you counterfeite,
Ile leaue the rogue till opportunity,
But neuer eate till I haue quit my wrong. Exit

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: I ſaw two men attend like holy Hermits,
One's ſlipt away, the other at his beades,
Now Richard for the loue of Marian,
Make thy inquiry where mad Gloſter liues.
If England or the verge of Scotland holde him,
Ile ſeeke him thus diſguiſ'd: if he be paſt
To any forraigne part; ile follow him.
Loue thou art Lord of hearts, thy lawes are ſweet,
In euery troubled way, thou guidſt our feete.
Louers inioyn'd to paſſe the daungerous Sea
Of big ſwolne ſorrow, in the Barke affection;
The windes and waues of woe need neuer feare,
While Loue, the helme doth like a Pylate ſteare.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Heer's ſome louer come, a miſchiefe on him,
I know not how to anſwere theſe mad fooles,
But ile be briefe, ile marre the Hermits tale;
Off gowne, holde Buckler, ſlice it bilbowe blade.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: What's this? what ſhould this meane? old man, good friend

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p: Young foole deliuer elſe ſee your end.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: I thought thou hadſt been holy and a Hermit.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: What ere you thought, your purſſe? come quickly ſir?
Caſt that vpon the ground, and then conferre.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: There it is.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p: Falles it ſo heauy? then my heart is light.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Thou't haue a heauy heart before thou touch it,
Theft ſhrinde in holy weedes? ſtand to't y'are beſt.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: And if I doe not, ſeeing ſuch a pray,
Let this be to me a diſaſter day.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: Art thou content to breath? Fight & part once or twiſe

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p: With al my heart, take halfe thy money & we'l friendly part.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: I will not cheriſh theft.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p: Then I defye thee. Fight againe and breath,

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Alas for pitty, that ſo ſtout a man,
So reuerend in aſpect, ſhould take this courſe.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: This is no common man with whom I fight,
And if he be, he is of wondrours ſpright,
Shall we part ſtakes?

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: Fellow take the purſſe vpon condition thou wilt follow me▪

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: What waite on you? weare a turn'd Liuery?
Whoſe man's your maſter? If I be your man,
My mans mans office will be excellent:
There lyes your purſſe againe, win it and weare it. Fight.

div.stage: Enter Robin Hood, they breath, offer againe.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Claſhing of weapons at my welcome hyther?
Bickring vpon Blacke-heath, well ſaid olde man,
Ile take thy ſide, the yonger hath the oddes.
Stay, end your quarrell, or I promiſe ye
Ile take the olde mans part.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: You were not wont yong Huntington, ſtil on Richards ſide

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Pardon gratious Prince I knew ye not.

sp.speaker: Gl.
sp.l: Prince Richard: then lye enuy at his foote,
Pardon thy couſen Gloſter, valiant Lord,
I knew no common force confronted myne,
O heauen I had the like conſeite of thine.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: I tell thee Robin Gloſter thou art met,
Bringing ſuch comfort vnto Richards heart.
As in the foyle of warre when duſt and ſweat,
The thirſt of weake, and the Sunnes fiery heate,
Haue ſeazd vppon the ſoule of valiaunce,
And he muſt faint except he be refreſht.
To me thou comſt as if to him ſhould come,
A perry from the North, whoſe froſtie breath
Might fan him coolneſſe in that doubt of death.
With me then meets, as he a ſpring might meet,
Cooling the earth vnder his toyle partcht feet,
Whoſe chriſtall moyſture in his Helmit taine,
Comforts his ſpyrits, makes him ſtrong againe.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Prince, in ſhort termes if you haue brought me comfort
Know if I had my pardon in this hand
That ſmit baſe Skinke in open Parlament,
I would not come to Court, till the high feaſt
Of your proud brothers birth day be expyred,
For as the o •• e King as he made a vow
At his vnluckie Coronation,
Muſt waite vpon the boy and fill his cuppe,
And all the Pieres muſt kneele while Henry kneeles
Vnto his cradle; he ſhall hang me vp,
Eare I commit that vile Idolatrie.
But when the feaſt is paſt if you'll befrend me,
Ile come and braue my proud foes to their teeth,

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Come Robin, and if my brothers grace denye,
Ile take thy parte, them and their threates defye,

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p: Gramercy Princly Dicke,

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: I haue ſome power, I can rayſe two thouſand Soldiers in an hower,

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Gramercy Robin, gramercy little wag,
Prince Richard, pray let Huntington
Carry my ſiſter Faukenbridge this ring,

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Ile carry it my ſelfe, but I had rather
Had thy kinde company, thou mightſt haue mou'd
Thy Siſter, whome I long haue vainely lou'd,

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: I like her that ſhe ſhunes temptation
Prince Richard, but I beare with doting louers,
I ſhould not take it well, that you vrge me
To ſuch an office: but I beare with you,
Loue's blind and mad, hie to her boldly, try her;
But if I know ſhe yeeld, faith Ile defie her.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: I like thy honorable reſolution,
Gloſter I pray thee pardon my intreate,

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: its mens cuſtome; part part Gentle Prince,
Farwell good Robin this gold I will borrow,
Meet you at ſtepney pay you all to morrow,

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: A dew Gloſter,

sp.speaker: Gl.
sp.p: Farwell, be ſhort; you gone, I hope to haue a little ſport

sp.speaker: Ric:
sp.p: Take heed mad Cuz. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Tut tell not me of heed,
He that's too wray neuer hath good ſpeed.
sp.stage: Hollowing within, Enter Lanc. with a broken ſtaffe in his hand.
sp.l: Whoſe this old Lancaſter my honoured frend?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Theſe knaues haue ſeru'd me well, left me alone,
I haue hunted fairely, loſt my purſe, my chaine,
My Iewels, and bin bangd by a bold knaue,
Clad in a Hermits gowne like an olde man,
O what a world is this?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p: Its ill my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Hee's come againe, O knaue tis the worſe for thee,
Keepe from me, be content with that thou haſt,
And ſee thou flie this heath, for if I take thee,
Ile make thee to all theeues aſpectacle,
Had my ſtaffe held, thou hadſt not ſcaped me ſo,
But come not neare me, follow not thou art beſt,
Holla, Earle Leyſter, holla Huntſman hoe?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Vppon my life, old Lancaſter a Hunting,
Hath met my fellow Hermit, could I meet him,
Ide play rob theefe, at leaſt part ſtakes with him.

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: Zounds he is yonder alone,
Skinke now reuenge thy ſelfe on yonder ſlaue.
Znayles ſtill preuented? this ſame Redcap rogue
Runs like hob-goblin vp and downe the heath.

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.l: Wh wh wh whope He Hermit, ye ha ha ma ma made
Re Redcap run a fine co co compaſſe, ha haue you not?

sp.speaker: Ski.
sp.p: I made thee run?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p: Younders my euill Angell, were redcap gone, Gloſter would coniure him.

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.p: Ie Ie Ieſus bl bleſſe me, whop to to two Hermits? Ile ca ca caperclaw to to tone of yee, for mo mo mocking me, and I d d doo not ha ha hang me: wh wh which is the fa fa falſe k k k knaue? for I am ſ ſ ſure the olde He He Hermit wo would neuer mo mocke an honeſt man.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: he is the counterfet he mockt thee fellow.
I did not ſee thee in my life before,
He weares my garments, and has couſſoned me,

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.l: Haue you co co couſoned the he Hermit and m made
Redcap run to no pu pu purpoſe?

sp.speaker: Ski.
sp.l: No he's counterfet I will tell no lyes,
As ſure as Skinke deceiu'd thee of thy clothes,
Sent thee to Kent, gaue thee thy fare by water,
So ſure hee's falſe, and I the perfet Hermit,

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: This villaine is a coniurer I doubt,
Were he the deuill yet I would not budge,

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.p: Si ſi ſirra, you are the co countefeite, O this is the tr tr true He Hermit, ſta ſta ſtand ſtill g good man at that, ile bu bumbaſt you yfaith, ile make you g giue the olde m m man his gowne.
sp.stage: Offers to ſtrike, Gloſter trippes vp his heeles, ſhifts Skinke into his place.
sp.p: G g gods lid are ye go good at that? ile cu cudgell yee f f for this tr tr tricke.

sp.speaker: Ski.
sp.p: It was not I twas he that caſt thee downe,

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.p: You li li li lye you ra ra raſcall you, I le left ye ſt ſtanding he heare.

sp.speaker: Ski.
sp.p: Zounds hold you ſtammerer, or Ile cut your ſtumps.

sp.speaker: Gl.
sp.p: He's for me he's weapon'd, I like that.

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.p: O heer's a ro ro rogue in ca ca carnat, help, mu murder murder.

div.stage: Enter Lancaſter & Huntſmen at one doore, Leyſter & Huntſmen at another.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Lay holde vpon that theeuiſh counterfeit,

sp.speaker: Ley.
sp.p: Why heares another Hermit Lancaſter:

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: I am the Hermit ſir, that wretched man
Doth many a robberie in my diſguiſe:

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.p: Its he that robs, he ſlaunders me, he lies.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Which ſet on thee?

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.p: Th this f f fellow has a ſ ſ ſword and a buckler.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Search him; this is the theefe, o heares my purſe,
My chaine, my Iewels: oh thou wicked wretch,
How darſt thou vnder ſhow of holines,
Commit ſuch actions of impietie?
Bind him, Ile haue him made a publicke ſcorne.

sp.speaker: Ski.
sp.l: Lay holde vpon that other hermit.
He is a counterfeit as well as I,
He ſtole thoſe clothes from me, for I am Skinke,
Search him, I know him not, he is ſome ſlaue.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p: Thou lyeſt baſe varlet.

sp.speaker: Re.
sp.p: O g God he has a ſword too, S Skink are you ca catcht?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Villaine thou ſhalt with me vnto the Court.

sp.speaker: Ley.
sp.p: And this with me, this is the traytor Gloſter.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p: Thou lyeſt proud Leyſter I am no traytor.

sp.speaker: Re.
sp.p: G gloſter? O b braue, now m my father ſh ſhal be f free

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Earle Gloſter I am ſorry thou art taken.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: I am not taken yet, nor will I yeild
To any heare but noble Lancaſter,
Let Skinke be Leyſters priſoner Ile be thine.

sp.speaker: Ley,
sp.p: Thou ſhalt be mine.

sp.speaker: Gl.
sp.l: Firſt through a crimſon ſluce, Ile ſend thy hated ſoule to thoſe blacke fiendes
That long haue houered gaping for their parte,
When tyrant life ſhould leaue thy traytor heart.
Come Lancaſter keep Skinke ile goe with thee,
Let looſe the mad knaue, for I prayſe his ſhifts,
He ſhall not ſtarte away, ile be his guide,
And with proude looks outface young Henries pride.

sp.speaker: Ley.
sp.p: Looke to them Lancaſter vpon thy life.

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.p:
Well ile r r run and get a p pardon of the K K KKing, Gl Gloſter and Skinke ta ta taken? O b b braue, r r r run re
Re Red ca cap a and ca ca cary the firſt n n newes to co co court.

sp.speaker: Ley.
sp.p: Lancaſter ile helpe to guarde them to the Court.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Doe as you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p: Leyſter doe not come neare me, for if thou doe, thou ſhalt buy it dearely.

sp.speaker: Ley.
sp.p: Ile haue thy hand for this.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p: Not for thy heart.

sp.speaker: Ski.
sp.p: Braue Earle, had Skinke knowne thou hadſt been the Noble Gloſter (whoſe mad trickes haue made mee loue thee) I would haue dy'd Blacke heath red with the bloud of millions, ere we would haue been taken; but what remedy, we are faſt & muſt anſwere it like Gentlemen, like Souldiers, like reſolutes.

sp.speaker: Gl.
sp.l: I ye are a gallant, come olde Lancaſter,
For thy ſake will I goe; or elſe by heauen
Ide ſend ſome dozen of theſe ſlaues to hel. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Prince Richard, Robert Hoode & Lady Faukenbridge.

sp.speaker: La,
sp.l: Your trauaile and your comfortable newes,
This Ring, the certaine ſigne you met with him,
Bindes me in duetyous loue vnto your grace:
But on my knees I fall, and humbly craue,
Importune that no more, you nere can haue.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Nay then ye wrong me Lady Faukenbridge,
Did you not ioyne your faire white hand?
Swore that ye would forſweare your husbands bed,
If I could but finde out Gloſter?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I ſweare ſo?

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: By heauen

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Take heed, its a high oath my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: What meanſt thou Huntington?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: To ſaue your ſoule, I doe not loue to haue my friends forſworne,
She neuer promiſt that you vrge her with.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: Goe to, prouoke me not.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: I tell you true, twas I in her attyre that promiſt you,
She was gone vnto the wizard at Blacke heath,
And there had ſuters more then a good many.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: Was I deluded then?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: No not deluded, but hindred from deſire vnchaſt and rude:
O let me wooe yee with the tongue of ruth,
Dewing your Princely hand with pitties teares,
That you would leaue this moſt vnlawful ſute,
If ere we liue till Faukenbridge be dead,
(As God defend his death I ſhould deſire)
Then if your highnes daine ſo baſe a match,
And holy lawes admit a mariage,
Conſidering our affinity in bloud,
I will become your Handmayde not your harlot.
That ſhame ſhall neuer dwell vpon my brow.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: I faith my Lord ſhe's honorably reſolu'd,
For ſhame no more, importune her no more.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Marian I ſee thy vertue, and commend it,
I know my error ſeeking thy dishonor,
But the reſpectleſſe, reaſonles commaund
Of my inflamed loue, bids me ſtill try,
And trample vnder foote all pietye.
Yet for I will not ſeeme too impyous,
Too inconſiderate of thy ſeeming griefe,
Vouchſafe to be my Miſtris: vſe me kindely,
And I proteſt ile ſtriue with all my power,
That luſt himſelfe may in his heate deuour.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: You are my ſeruant then.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: Thankes ſacred Miſtreſſe.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: What am I?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: You are my fellow Robert.

div.stage: Enter Faukenbridge in his hoſe and dublet.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: What Prince Richard? noble Huntington?
Welcome, yfaith welcome, by the morrow Maſſe
You are come as fitly as my heart can wiſh:
Prince Iohn this night will be a Reueller,
He hath inuited me and Marian.
Gods mary mother goe along with vs,
Its but hard by, cloſe by, at our towne Tauerne.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: Your Tauerne?

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: O I I I tis his owne made match,
Ile make you laugh, ile make you laugh yfaith;
Come, come, he's ready, O come, come away.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: But wher's the Princeſſe?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: He's ready too, Block Bl. my man, muſt be her waiting man,
Nay wil ye goe? for gods ſake let vs goe.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: Is the ieſt ſo? nay then let vs away.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: O twill allay his heate, make dead his fire.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Ye bob'd me firſt, ye firſt gaue me my hyre,
But come a gods name, Prince Iohn ſtayes for vs. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: This is the word, euer at ſpend-thriftes feaſtes,
They are guld themſelues, and ſcoft at by their gueſts. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Buffild and ſcoft, Skinke, Gloſter, women, fooles, and boyes abuſe me?
Ile be reueng'd,

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Reueng'd, and why good childe?
Olde Faukenbridge hath had a worſer baſting.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: I, they haue banded from chaſe to chaſe;
I haue been their tennis ball, ſince I did coort,

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Come Iohn, take hand with vertuous Iſabell,
And lets vnto the Court like louing friends,
Our Kingly brothers birth daies feaſtiuall,
Is foorthwith to be kept, thether we'l hye,
And grace with pompe that great ſolemnity.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Whether ye wil, I care not where I goe:
If griefe wil grace it, ile adorne the ſhew.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Come Madam, we muſt thither we are bound.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I am loath to ſee the Court, Gloſter being from thence,
Or kneele to him that gaue vs this offence.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Body of me peace woman. I prethee peace.

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.p: Go go god ye, go god ſ ſpeed ye,

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.p: Whether run you ſir knaue?

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.p: R r run ye ſir knaue? why I r run to my La Lady Fa Faukenbridge, to te te tell her Sk Skinke and Gl Gloſter is t taken, and are gg one to the CC Court with L Lord Leyſter, and L Lord la la Lancaſter.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Is Gloſter taken? thether will I flye
Vpon wraths wings, not quiet til he dye. Exit with Princeſſe

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Is Gloſter taken?

sp.speaker: Red:
sp.p: I he is ta taken I wa warrant ye with a wi witnes,

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Then will I to Court, & eyther ſet him free, or dye the death,
Follow me Faukenbridge, feare not faire Madam:
You ſaid you had the Porter in your houſe,
Some of your ſeruants bring him, on my life
One hayre ſhal not be taken from his head,
Nor he, nor you, nor Gloſter iniured.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Come Mall, and Richard ſay the word nere feare.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Madam, we haue twenty thouſand at our call,
The moſt, young Henry dares, is but to braule.

sp.speaker: La:
sp.p: Pray God it prooue ſo.

sp.speaker: Ric:
sp.p: Follow Huntington: ſir Rich. doe not faile to ſend the Porter.

sp.speaker: Fa:
sp.p: Blocke, bring the Porter of the Fleete to Court.

sp.speaker: Bl.
sp.p: I wil ſir.

sp.speaker: Red:
sp.p: The p p Porter of the fl fl Fleete to Court? what p p porter of the fl fl Fleete?

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.p: What Redcap, run redcap, wilt thou ſee thy father?

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.p: My fa father? I that I w wold ſ ſee my f father, & there be a p porter in your ho houſe, its my f fa ••• r.

sp.speaker: Bl.
sp.p: Follow me Redcap then. Exit.

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.p: And you were two to twenty b Blockes, ide f f follow ye ſ ſo I would, and r run to the co co court too, and k kneele before the k k King f f for his pa pardon.

sp.speaker: Block within.
sp.p: Come away Redcap, run Redcap.

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.p: I I I r r run as f f faſt as I I ca ca can run I wa warrant yee.

div.stage: Enter a Sinet, firſt two Herraldos, after them Leyſter with a Scepter, Lancaſter with a Crowne Imperiall on a cuſhion: After them Henry the elder bareheaded, bearing a ſwoord and a Globe: after him young Henry Crowned: Elinor the mother Queene Crowned: young Queene Crowned. Henry the elder places his Sonne, the two Queenes on eyther hand, himſelfe at his feete, Leyſter and Lancaſter below him.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Herrald, fetch Lancaſter and Leyſter Coronets,
Suffer no Marqueſſe, Earle, nor Counteſſe enter,
Except their temples circled are in golde,
sp.stage: He deliuers Coronets to Leyſter and Lancaſter.
sp.l: Shew them our vize-roys: by our will controld
As at a cornation, euery Peere
Appeares in all his pompe, ſo at this feaſt
Held for our birth-right, let them be adorn'd.
Let Gloſter be brought in, crown'd like an Earle, Exit
This day we'll haue no parley of his death,
But talke of Iouiſanes and gleefull mirth.
Let Skinke come in, giue him a Barons ſeat,
High is his ſpirrit, his deſerts are greate.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: You wrong the honour of Nobilitie,
To place a robber in a Barons ſtead,

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.p: Its well ye tearme him not a murtherer.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.p: Had I miſtearmed him?

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: I that had you Henry.
He did a peece of Iuſtice at my Bidding.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.p: Who made you a Iuſtice?

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: I that had the power.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.p: You had none then.

sp.speaker: Ley.
sp.p: Yes he was crownd before.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Why does not Gloſter weare a Coronet?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p: Becauſe his Soueraigne doth not weare a Crowne.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: By heauen put on thy Coronet, or that heauen
Which now with a clear, lends vs this light,
Shall not be courtain'd with the vaile of night,
Eare on thy head I clap a burning Crowne,
Of red hot Yron that ſhall ſeare thy braines.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: Good Gloſter Crowne thee with thy Coronet.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Doo gentle Earle.

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.p: Swounds doo, would I had one.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: Doo not I prethee keepe thy proud heart ſtill.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p: Ile weare it but to croſſe thy froward will.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Sit downe and take thy place.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Its the low earth.
To her I muſt, from her I had my breath.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: We are pleaſ'd thou ſhalt ſit there, Skinke take thy place among my nobles.

stage.hi: Enter Iohn and Jſabell with Coronets.

sp.speaker: Ski.
sp.p: Thankes to King Henries grace.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Iohn Earle of Morton and of Notingham,
With Iſabell his Counteſſe, bow themſelues
Before their brother Henries Royall Throane.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Aſſend your ſeats liue in our daily loue.

div.stage: Enter Richard, and Robert with Coronts.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Richard the Prince of England, with his Ward
The noble Robert Hood, Earle Huntington,
Preſent their ſeruice to your Maieſtie.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Y'are welcome too, though little be your loue.

div.stage: Enter Faukenbridge with his Lady, ſhe a Coronet

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Olde Richard Faukenbridge, Knight of the croſſe,
Lord of the Cinque ports, with his noble wife
Dame Marrian Counteſſe of weſt Hereford,
Offer their duties at this Royall meeting.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Sit downe, thou art a newter, ſhe a foe,
Thy loue we doubt her hart too well we know.
What ſutors are without, let them come in.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p: And haue no Iuſtice where contempt is King.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Mad man I giue no eare to thy looſe words.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: O ſir y'are welcome, you haue your old ſeat.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p: Though thou ſit hier yet my heart's as great.

sp.speaker: Que.
sp.p: Great heart wee'll make you leſſer by the head.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p: Ill comes not euer to the threatned.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: What are you two?

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.p: M ma mary and't pleaſe you I am re re Redcap.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: And what's your mate?

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.p: A poore Porter ſir.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.p: The Porter of the fleet that was condemned.

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.l: No truely ſir I was Porter laſt, when I left
The doore open at the Tauerne.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: O iſt you ſir?

sp.speaker: Ley.
sp.p: And what would you two haue?

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.p: I co co come to re re re qui quier the young K K King of his go goo goodnes, ſince Glo Gloſter is t taken, that he wo wo would let my fa fa father haue his pa pa pardon.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Sirra your father has his pardon ſign'd,
Go to the office it ſhall be deliuered.

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.p: And ſhall he be p p Porter a ga gaine?

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: I that he ſhall, but let him be aduiſ'd
Heareafter, how lets out priſoners,

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.p: I wa warrant ye my Lord.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: What haſt thou more to ſay?

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.p: Marry I wo would haue Skinke pu puniſht for co co Cunnicatching me.

sp.speaker: Ley,
sp.p: Is that your buſines?

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.p: I by my t t troth is it.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Then get away.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Againſt Skinke (poore knaue)
Thou gets no right this day.

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.p: O but run backe Redcap for the Purſeuant.

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.p: O I Lord ſ ſir, I haue another ſ ſute for the p p Purſeuant, that has l l loſt his b b box, and his wa wa warrant.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: What meanes the fellow?

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.p: Why the pu pu Purſeuant ſir and the po po Porter.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p: The box that I had from him, there it is.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Mary a me, and I was chargd with it.
Had you it brother Gloſter? Gods good mercy,

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: And what haue you to ſay?

sp.speaker: Bl.
sp.p: Nothing ſir but God bleſſe you, you are a goodly company, except ſir William or my Lady wil command me any more ſeruice.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.p: A way you prating knaue, hence varlet, hence. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ley.
sp.p: Put forth them fellowes there.

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.p: A f fo fore I go goe I b b be ſ ſ ſeech you let Sk Skinke and gl Gloſter be lo lo looked too, for they haue p p playd the k k knaues to to to b b bad.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Take hence that ſtuttering fellow, ſhut them forth.

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.p: Nay Ile ru ru run, faith you ſhall not n n need to b b b bid him ta ta take m me away, for re re Redcap will r ru run rarely. Exit.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: The ſundrie miſdemeanors late committed,
As theftes and ſhifts in other mens diſguiſe,
We now muſt (knaue Skinke) freely tell thy faults.

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.p: Sweet King by theſe two terrors to myne enemies, that lend light to my bodies darknes: Cauilero Skinke being beleagerd with an hoſte of leaden heeles, arm'd in ring Iriſh: cheated my hammerer of his Red cap and Coate; was ſurpriſed, brought to the fleet as a perſon ſuſpected, paſt currant, till Gloſter ſtript me from my counterfet, clad my backe in ſilke and my hart in ſorrow, and ſo left me to the mercy of my mother witt: how Prince Iohn releaſt me, he knowes: howe I got Faukenbridges chaine, I know: but how he will get it againe, I know not.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.p: Where is it ſirra, tell me where it is?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p: I got it from him, and I got Iohns ſword,

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.p: I would twere to the hilts vp in thy harte.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: O be more charitable brother Iohn.

sp.speaker: Ley.
sp.l: My Leidge, you need not by perticulars
Examine what the world knows too plaine,
If you will pardon Skinke, his life is ſau'd,
If not, he is conuicted by the Law.
For Gloſter: as you worthyly reſoul'd,
Firſt take his hand, and afterward his head.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Skinke thou haſt life, our pardon and our loue.

sp.speaker: Ski.
sp.p: And your forgiueneſſe for my robbery?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Tut neuer trouble me with ſuch a toy.
Thou hindreſt me from hearing of my ioye.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Bring forth a blocke, wine, water and towell,
Kniues, and a Surgion to binde vp the vaines,
Of Gloſters arme: when his right hand is off,
His hand that ſtrooke Skinke at the Parlament:

sp.speaker: Sk.
sp.p: I ſhall beare his blowes to my graue my Lord.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Sonne Henry ſee thy fathers palzie hands,
Ioyn'd like two ſupplyants, preſſing to thy throwne?
Looke how the furrowes of his aged cheeke,
Fild with the reuolets of wet eyde mone,
Begs mercy for Earle Gloſter? weigh his gilt,
Why for a ſlaue, ſhould Royall blood be ſpilt?

sp.speaker: Ski.
sp.p: You wrong myne honour: Skink may be reueng'd,

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Father I doe commend your humble courſe.
But quite diſlike the proiect of your ſute,
Good words in an ill cauſe makes the fact worſe,
Of blood or Baſenes, Iuſtice will diſpute,
The greater man the greater his tranſgreſſion,
Where ſtrength wrongs weaknes, it is meare oppreſſion,

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: O but King Henry heare a ſiſter ſpeake,
Gloſter was wrong'd, his lands were giuen away,
They are not Iuſtly ſaid. Iuſt lawes to break,
That keep their owne right, with what power they may,
Thinke then thy Royall ſelfe began the wrong,
In giuing Skinke what did to him belong.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Heare me Sonne Henry, while thou art a King,
Giue, take, pryſon, thy ſubiects are thy ſlaues,
Life, need, thrones proud hearts in dungions fling.
Grace men to day, to morrowe giue them graues.
A King muſt be like Fortune; euer turning,
The world his football, all her glory ſpurning.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Still your olde counſaile Beldam pollicie,
You'r a fit Tutreſſe in a Monarchy.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Mother you are vniuſt, ſauage, too cruell,
Vnlike a woman: gentlenes guides their ſexe,
But you to furyes fire ad more fewell,
The vexed ſpirit, will you delight to vex?
O God when I conſaite what you haue done,
I am a ſham'd to be eſtem'd your ſonne.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Baſe Richard I diſdaine to call thee brother,
Takeſt thou a traytors part in our diſgrace?
For Gloſter, wilt thou wrong our ſacred mother?
I ſcorne thee and defie thee to thy face.
O that we were in field, then ſhouldſt thou trie,

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: How faſt Earle Iohn would from Prince Richard flye
Thou meet a Lyon in feeld? poore mouſe,
All thy Carreers are in a Brothell houſe.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.p: Zounds boy.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: Now man:

sp.speaker: Ley.
sp.p: Richard you wrong Prince Iohn.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: Leyſter tweare Good you proou'd his Champion.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Haſten the execution Royall Lord,
Let deeds make anſwer for their worthleſſe wordes.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: I know if I reſpected hand or head,
I am encompaſſed with a world of frends,
And could from fury bee deliuered.
But then my freedom hazards many liues.
Henry performe the vtmoſt of thy hate,
Let thy hard harted mother haue her wil,
Giue Franticke Iohn no longer cauſe to prate,
I am prepared for the worſt of ill,
You ſee my knees kiſſe the could pauements face,
They are not bent to Henry nor his frends,
But to all you whoſe bloud fled to your hearts,
Shewes your true ſorrowe in your aſhye cheekes:
To you I bend my knees, you I intreat,
To ſmile on Gloſters Reſolution.
Who euer loues me will not ſhed a teare,
Nor breath a ſigh, nor ſhow a cloudy frowne,
Looke Henry, heares my hand, I lay it downe,
And ſweare as I haue Knighthood heer't ſhall lye,
Till thou haue vſed all thy tyranny.

sp.speaker: La.
