sp.p: Has no man heart to ſpeake?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p: Let all that loue me keepe ſilence, or by heauen Ile hate them dying.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.p: Harry off with his hand, then with his head.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: By the red rood I cannot chuſe but weepe.
Come loue or hate my teares I cannot keepe.

sp.speaker: Que.
sp.p: When comes this lingring executioner?

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.p: An executioner: an executioner:

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Call none till we haue drunke: father fill wine,
To day your Office is to beare our cupp.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: Ile fill it Henry. K. kneele downe.

sp.speaker: He.
sp.p: Dick you are too meane, ſo bow vnto your ſoueraigne,

sp.speaker: Gl.
sp.l: Kneele to his childe? O hell! O tortor! (Gloſter learne:
Who would loue life, to ſee this huge diſhonor?

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Saturne kneel'd to his Sonne the God was faine
To call young Ioue his ages Soveraigne.
Take now your ſeate againe and weare your Crowne;
Now ſhineth Henry like the Middayes Sonne,
Through his Horizon, darting all his beames,
Blinding with his bright ſplendor euery eye,
That ſtares againſt his face of Maieſty.
The Commets, whoſe malicious gleames
Threatned the ruyne of our Royalty,
Stands at our mercy, yet our wrath denyes
All fauour, but extreame extreamityes.
Gloſter, haue to thy ſorrow chafe thy arme
That I may ſee thy bloud (I long'd for oft)
Guſh from thy vaines, and ſtaine this Pallace roofe.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: Twould exceed gilding.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.p: I as golde doth Oaker.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p: Its wel ye count my bloud ſo precious.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Leyſter reach Gloſter wine.

sp.speaker: Ley.
sp.p: I reach it him?

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Proude Earle ile ſpurne thee, quickely go & beare it

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p: Ile count it poyſon if his hand come neere it.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Giue it him Leyſter vpon our diſpleaſure.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Thus Gloſter takes it, thus againe he flings it,
In ſcorne of him that ſent it, and of him that brought it.

sp.speaker: Ski.
sp.p: O braue ſpirit▪

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Brauely reſolu'd brother, I honour thee.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Harke how his ſiſter ioyes in his abuſe?
Wilt thou indure it Hall?

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.p: Peace good Marian.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Auoyde there euery vnder Officer.
Leaue but vs, our Pieres and Ladyes heere.
Richard you loue Earle Gloſter looke about
If you can ſpye one in this company,
That hath not done as great a ſinne as Gloſter;
Chuſe him, let him be the executioner.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Thou haſt done worſe then, like rebellie us head,
Haſt arm'd ten thouſand hands againſt his life
That lou'd thee ſo, as thou wert made a King,
Being his childe, now he's thy vnderling.
I haue done worſe: thriſe I drew my ſwoord,
In three ſet battles for thy falſe defence.
Iohn hath done worſe, he ſtill hath tooke thy part,
All of vs three haue ſmitte our fathers heart;
Which made proude Leyſter bolde to ſtrike his face,
To his eternall ſhame, and our diſgrace.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Silence, I ſee thou leanſt to finde none fit.
I am ſure, nor Lancaſter nor Huntington,
Nor Faukenbridge, will lay a hand on him.
Mother, wife, brother, lets deſcend the Throane
Where Henry is the Monarch of the Weſt,
Hath ſet amongſt his Princes dignified.
Father take you the place, ſee Iuſtice.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.p: Its iniuſt Iuſtice I muſt tell thee Sonne.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Mother holde you the Baſon, you the Towell,
I know your French hearts thirſt for Engliſh bloud;
Iohn, take the Mallet, I will holde the knife,
And when I bid thee ſmite, ſtrike for thy life:
Make a marke Surgion, Gloſter now prepare thee.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p: Tut, I am ready, to thy worſt I dare thee.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Then haue I done my worſt, thriſe honoured Earle,
I doe imbrace thee in affections armes.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.p: What meanes thou Henry? O what meanes my Son?

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: I meane no longer to be lullaby'd,
In your ſeditious armes.

sp.speaker: Hen. wife.
sp.p: Mordieu Henry.

sp.speaker: Hen:
sp.l: Mordieu nor deuill, little tit of Fraunce,
I know your hart leapes, at our hearts miſchaunce,

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: Swounds Henry thou art mad:

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: I haue bin mad; what ſtampſt thou Iohn? knowſt thou not who I am?
Come ſtamp the deuill out, ſuckt from thy Dam.

sp.speaker: Que.
sp.p: Ile curſſe thee Henry.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Your beſt be quiet, leaſt where we finde you, to the Tower we beare you,
For being abroad, England hath cauſe to feare yee.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.p: I am ſtrucke dombe with wonder.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p: I amaz'd, imagine that I ſee a vizion.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Gloſter, I giue thee firſt this Skinke, this ſlaue,
Its in thy power, his life to ſpill or ſaue,

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.p: He's a noble gentleman, I doe not doubt his vſage.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Stand not thus wondring, Princes kneele all downe,
And caſt your Coronets before his Crowne.
Downe ſtubborne Queene, kneele to your wronged King,
Downe Mammet; Leyſter ile cut of thy legs,
If thou delay thy duety: when proude Iohn?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: Nay if all kneele, of force I muſt be one.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.p: Now by my holydom a vertuous deed.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Father you ſee your moſt rebellious ſonne,
Stricken with horror of his horred guilt,
Requeſting ſentence fitting his deſart,
O treade vpon his head, that trode your heart.
I doe deliuer vp all dignity,
Crowne, Scepter, ſwoord vnto your Maieſty.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: My heart ſurfets with ioy in hearing this.
And deare Sonne ile bleſſe thee with a kiſſe.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: I will not riſe, I will not leaue this ground,
Till all theſe voyces ioyned in one ſound:
Cry, God ſaue Henry ſecond of that name,
Let his friends liue, his foes ſee death with ſhame.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: God ſaue Henry ſecond of that name,
Let his friends liue, his foes ſee death with ſhame.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Amen, Amen, Amen.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: Harke mother harke?
My brother is already turned Clarke.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.p: He is a recreant, I am mad with rage.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Be angry at your enuy gracious mother,
Learne patience and true humility
Of your worſt tuter'd Sonne, for I am he.
Send hence that Frenchwoman, giue her her dowry,
Let her not ſpeake, to trouble my milde ſoule,
Which of this world hath taken her laſt leaue:
And by her power, will my proude fleſh controule.
Off with theſe ſilkes, my garments ſhall be gray,
My ſhirt hard hayre, my bed the aſhey duſt,
My pillow but a lumpe of hardned clay:
For clay I am, and vnto clay I muſt,
O I beſeech ye let me goe alone,
To liue, where my looſe life I may bemone.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.p: Sonne?

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.p: Sonne?

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: Brother?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: Brother?

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Let none call me their Sonne, I am no mans brother,
My kindred is in heauen, I know no other,
Farewell, farewell, the world is yours, pray take it,
Ile leaue vexation, and with ioy forſake it. Exit.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Wondrous conuerſion.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.p: Admirable good: now by my holydam Mall paſſing good.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: H'ath ſir'd my ſoule I will to Paleſtine,
And pay my vowes before the Sepulcher,
Among the multitude of misbeliefe.
Ile ſhew my ſelfe the Souldier of Chriſt,
Spend bloud, ſweat teares, for ſatiſfaction
Of many many ſinnes which I lament:
And neuer thinke to haue them pardoned,
Till I haue part of Sirria conquered.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: He makes me wonder, and inflames my ſpirits,
With an exceeding zeale to Portingale,
Which Kingdome the vnchriſtned Sariſons,
The blacke fac'd Affricans, and tawny Moores,
Haue got vniuſtly in poſſeſſion:
Whence I will fire them with the help of heauen.

sp.speaker: Ski.
sp.l: Skinke will ſcotrch them braue Gloſter
Make Carbonadoes of their Bacon fletches;
Deſerue to be counted valiant by his valour,
And Ryuo will he cry, and Caſtile too,
And wonders in the land of Ciuile doo.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: O that I were a man to ſee theſe fights,
To ſpend my bloud amongſt theſe worthy Knights.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Mary aye me, were I a boy againe,
Ide either to Ieruſalem or Spaine.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Faith Ile keepe England, mother you and I
Will liue, for all this fight and foolery.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Peace to vs all, let's all for peace giue prayſe,
Vnlookt for peace, vnlookt for happy dayes.
Loue Henries birth day, he hath bin new borne,
I am new crowned, new ſettled in my ſeate.
Lets' all to the Chappell, there giue thankes and praiſe,
Beſeeching grace from Heauens eternal Throne,
That England neuer know more Prince then one. Exeunt
